I was curious to see whether "$T$" (first novel in a fantasy series that has since worked its way up to Thursday) was published before or after James Stoddard's "High House" as the two books have similar settings [SEP] Stoddard came first, but Garth Nix has put his unique stamp on the 'Universe manifested as a queer old House' theme [SEP] That said, this "Keys to the Kingdom" series is more disjointed and less appealing than Garth Nix's Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] "$T$" reminds me more of "The Ragwitch" in that a young boy with absolutely no training learns that he is the Rightful Heir to some improbable kingdom (the Universe) and is also the only person on Earth who can stop/cure the newest, deadliest plague [SEP] Naturally Arthur wants to concentrate on curing the plague, since his own family is involved [SEP] Then he is saved from a lethal asthma attack by a man in a bath chair wielding the minute hand off of a gigantic clock [SEP] The man in the bath chair is Mr [SEP] Monday and he is being pushed about by his butler, Sneezer [SEP] These two men spend the rest of the book chasing Arthur through a sort of Victorian workers' hell, trying to get him to return the Key (the minute hand) to Mr [SEP] Monday [SEP] The book has lots of interesting magic, blue-and-yellow-striped dinosaurs, an angry old man who is chained to a gigantic clock, and a pair of truly macabre creatures who gouge out the old man's eyes every day at 12 o'clock [SEP] (His eyes grow back [SEP] Does this man remind you of Prometheus, kiddies?) [SEP] Arthur must get through some horrifying trials to save his Earth from the plague, and to prove that he is the Rightful Heir [SEP] He shows that he has the Right Stuff--after all, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday have already been written--but this first book suffers from a multiplicity of themes [SEP] The author seems to have tried out several different settings (Victorian policemen and a sort of Bob Cratchit universe, along with dinosaurs, good and bad angels, and a really stinky and terrifying Roman bathhouse), then didn't want to discard anything [SEP] So, here it all is in "$T$ [SEP] " [SEP] I'm still debating as to whether I want to advance on to "Grim Tuesday [SEP] " Arthur has already saved my world from the Sleepy Plague and I'm not particularly taken with the rest of Nix's mixed-up Universe

I've borrowed this $T$ from the school library [SEP] Well, what I can say about this $T$ is,it's very interesting [SEP] It is about a pair of twins [SEP] One is good(called Jill),another is bad(called Jane) [SEP] But later their parents made them to be christian and the good one called Angela while the bad one called Diabola [SEP] Everyone loves Angela much and hate Diabola [SEP] When the twins grow up, they have power to do good things and bad things [SEP] Of course, the good one do good and the bad one do bad [SEP] Their power were so strong that the bad one can make people sick by using her eyes and the good one can cure them if she want [SEP] I think this $T$ is really interesting because no $T$ I've read have got such extreme case

I was curious to see whether "$T$" (first novel in a fantasy series that has since worked its way up to Thursday) was published before or after James Stoddard's "High House" as the two books have similar settings [SEP] Stoddard came first, but Garth Nix has put his unique stamp on the 'Universe manifested as a queer old House' theme [SEP] That said, this "Keys to the Kingdom" series is more disjointed and less appealing than Garth Nix's Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] "$T$" reminds me more of "The Ragwitch" in that a young boy with absolutely no training learns that he is the Rightful Heir to some improbable kingdom (the Universe) and is also the only person on Earth who can stop/cure the newest, deadliest plague [SEP] Naturally Arthur wants to concentrate on curing the plague, since his own family is involved [SEP] Then he is saved from a lethal asthma attack by a man in a bath chair wielding the minute hand off of a gigantic clock [SEP] The man in the bath chair is Mr [SEP] Monday and he is being pushed about by his butler, Sneezer [SEP] These two men spend the rest of the book chasing Arthur through a sort of Victorian workers' hell, trying to get him to return the Key (the minute hand) to Mr [SEP] Monday [SEP] The book has lots of interesting magic, blue-and-yellow-striped dinosaurs, an angry old man who is chained to a gigantic clock, and a pair of truly macabre creatures who gouge out the old man's eyes every day at 12 o'clock [SEP] (His eyes grow back [SEP] Does this man remind you of Prometheus, kiddies?) [SEP] Arthur must get through some horrifying trials to save his Earth from the plague, and to prove that he is the Rightful Heir [SEP] He shows that he has the Right Stuff--after all, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday have already been written--but this first book suffers from a multiplicity of themes [SEP] The author seems to have tried out several different settings (Victorian policemen and a sort of Bob Cratchit universe, along with dinosaurs, good and bad angels, and a really stinky and terrifying Roman bathhouse), then didn't want to discard anything [SEP] So, here it all is in "$T$ [SEP] " [SEP] I'm still debating as to whether I want to advance on to "Grim Tuesday [SEP] " Arthur has already saved my world from the Sleepy Plague and I'm not particularly taken with the rest of Nix's mixed-up Universe

Already a huge fan of $T$, via Sabriel & co [SEP] , I admit I came into Mister Monday with rather high expectations [SEP] As far as story goes, Mr [SEP] Nix certainly did not disappoint [SEP] It is captivating from beginning to end with an extraordinary imaginative quality that is his trademark [SEP] However, 2 qualms I have with the book prevent me from giving it full marks [SEP] First, the overuse of what seems to be the main character's (Arthur) only fault: his asthma [SEP] The first asthma attack successfully helps readers to sympathize with Arthur [SEP] However, by the end of the first 100 pages, you feel like screaming, "GET AN INHALER AND SHUT UP!" So much so, I jokingly told my friend that Mister Monday's real title is The Amazing Adventures of Asthmatic Arthur [SEP] The belaboring of this point is very distracting, though humorous [SEP] Secondly, the narrative isn't up to par with Mr [SEP] Nix's previous work [SEP] It's often choppy or unclear and I would imagine that its targetted age group would have difficulty following his train of thought [SEP] But, overall, Mister Monday is a page turner that's so creative and captivating, its shortcomings are largely made up for

So much so, I jokingly told my friend that Mister Monday's real title is The Amazing Adventures of Asthmatic Arthur [SEP] The belaboring of this point is very distracting, though humorous [SEP] Secondly, the narrative isn't up to par with Mr [SEP] $T$'s previous work [SEP] It's often choppy or unclear and I would imagine that its targetted age group would have difficulty following his train of thought [SEP] But, overall, Mister Monday is a page turner that's so creative and captivating, its shortcomings are largely made up for

$T$ writer Garth Nix expanded his readership with his excellent "Seventh Tower" series, an original and much-publicized fantasy work [SEP] Now he expands further, in a darker, grittier, more realistic fantasy set in our world, where a confused young boy has to escape dark forces that want to use him for their own ends -- or kill him [SEP] Arthur Penhaligon has asthma [SEP] As a result, he ends up in the hospital regularly [SEP] But one day he encounters a strange man called Mr [SEP] Monday and his creepy butler, who leave him with a Key shaped like a minute hand and a little book with dancing letters [SEP] When he returns home after another stay in the hospital, Arthur finds that the Key seems to be attracting unwanted attention -- a statue of a Komodo dragon comes alive, and a winged man-dog tries to come into his house [SEP] What's more, a House has appeared -- one that is also inside the little book [SEP] Soon Arthur is being pursued by more dog-faced Fetchers, and a strange plague is sweeping his town -- and somehow the Key is keeping him alive, even though he was supposed to die of an asthma attack [SEP] His answers lie inside the House [SEP] But what lies beyond it is like nothing in our world, where ghastly nithlings roam and the Piper's children run wild in the streets [SEP] And the sinister Mr [SEP] Monday wants the Key back [SEP] Garth Nix takes his focus from high fantasy -- such as the Abhorsen trilogy or the Seventh Tower series -- to a more modern fantasy that takes place in our world [SEP] Though Arthur skips to another world, he's clearly from our own [SEP] But Nix doesn't downplay his brand of horrific fantasy either; stuff that would seem silly for most other authors, like dog-faced monsters, is magic in his hands [SEP] The writing is detailed, evocative, and never lags for a minute [SEP] As in his other books, he melds an exceptional, original fantasy world with elements of horror [SEP] The handling of the parallel world, the Will, Sneezer, and the Key and Atlas are all wonderfully woven together, not to mention the characters of Dawn, Dusk, Noon for each day, and so on [SEP] At the same time, we have the bloodwinged, silver-tongued Noon and the ugly Fetchers, not to mention the hideous nithlings [SEP] This is dark fantasy at its best [SEP] Arthur is a likable kid, with an unusual problem for fantasy heroes (namely, asthma) [SEP] Like most of Nix's heroes, the poor kid is desperately running and searching, and learning from those ahead of him [SEP] Quirky Suzy is reminiscent of a Lloyd Alexander heroine, strong and brave and just a little strange [SEP] "Mister Monday" is another great book from Garth Nix, combining darkness and fantasy and leaving the ending open for the second book of the series [SEP] An intriguing, enthralling book

stuff that would seem silly for most other authors, like dog-faced monsters, is magic in his hands [SEP] The writing is detailed, evocative, and never lags for a minute [SEP] As in his other $T$s, he melds an exceptional, original fantasy world with elements of horror [SEP] The handling of the parallel world, the Will, Sneezer, and the Key and Atlas are all wonderfully woven together, not to mention the characters of Dawn, Dusk, Noon for each day, and so on [SEP] At the same time, we have the bloodwinged, silver-tongued Noon and the ugly Fetchers, not to mention the hideous nithlings [SEP] This is dark fantasy at its best [SEP] Arthur is a likable kid, with an unusual problem for fantasy heroes (namely, asthma) [SEP] Like most of Nix's heroes, the poor kid is desperately running and searching, and learning from those ahead of him [SEP] Quirky Suzy is reminiscent of a Lloyd Alexander heroine, strong and brave and just a little strange [SEP] "Mister Monday" is another great $T$ from Garth Nix, combining darkness and fantasy and leaving the ending open for the second $T$ of the series [SEP] An intriguing, enthralling $T$

As much as I like these kinds of surreal books, I haven't seen too many authors that go this route [SEP] Their heart just isn't in it [SEP] So I'm very happy to see such a rare, daring $T$ like Mister Monday in print [SEP] The book starts off with a wild prologue that sets up the Keys to the Kingdom series [SEP] Words write themselves through the air on some kind of distant star [SEP] Very strange [SEP] It takes about two chapters or so before the reader adjusts to the insane style [SEP] The main character Arthur has just moved to a new school (typical of children's books) and is plagued with asthma [SEP] (Currently, main characters in the publishing industry are always made out to be weak underdogs at first [SEP] Forget the old-fashioned Conan the Barbarian style [SEP] ) [SEP] Arthur's immediately visited by the sleepy Mister Monday and his butler Sneezer, and is given a key in the shape of a clock hand [SEP] Arthur is afterwards harassed and pursued by guys in bowler hats named Fetchers - imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to de$T$ Mister Monday, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach Mister Monday's dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] Mister Monday's lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With Mister Monday de$T$ed, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?"  Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the Greek guy seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author Garth Nix doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought Mister Monday for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to defeat $T$, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach $T$'s dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] $T$'s lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With $T$ defeated, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?"  Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the Greek guy seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author Garth Nix doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought $T$ for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to defeat Mister Monday, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach Mister Monday's dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] Mister Monday's lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With Mister Monday defeated, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?" Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the Greek guy seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author Garth Nix doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought Mister Monday for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to defeat $T$, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach $T$'s dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] $T$'s lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With $T$ defeated, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?"  Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the Greek guy seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author Garth Nix doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought $T$ for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the $T$ seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author Garth Nix doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought Mister Monday for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

As much as I like these kinds of surreal books, I haven't seen too many authors that go this route [SEP] Their heart just isn't in it [SEP] So I'm very happy to see such a rare, daring feat like Mister Monday in print [SEP] The book starts off with a wild prologue that sets up the Keys to the Kingdom series [SEP] Words write themselves through the air on some kind of distant star [SEP] Very strange [SEP] It takes about two chapters or so before the reader adjusts to the insane style [SEP] The main character Arthur has just moved to a new school (typical of children's books) and is plagued with asthma [SEP] (Currently, main characters in the publishing industry are always made out to be weak underdogs at first [SEP] Forget the old-fashioned Conan the Barbarian style [SEP] ) [SEP] Arthur's immediately visited by the sleepy Mister Monday and his butler Sneezer, and is given a key in the shape of a clock hand [SEP] Arthur is afterwards harassed and pursued by guys in bowler hats named Fetchers - imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to defeat Mister Monday, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach Mister Monday's dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] Mister Monday's lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With Mister Monday defeated, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?"  Ed and Leaf may be useful throughout later books in the series, but the Greek guy seems to have been a boo-boo [SEP] Unless there's some place in the book I missed, mentioning that someone on the improbable stair is able to understand all languages [SEP] Despite my best efforts to read every word, it is possible for me to skip/forget certain things [SEP] The book has a sentence saying evolution is a fact [SEP] Of course the entire scientific community agrees, but Christian readers should be aware of this [SEP] From what I've heard, the author $T$ doesn't believe in any religion, and you can see this reflected in the main character Arthur at one point [SEP] I bought Mister Monday for a special price of $2 [SEP] 99 and it includes an enlighting author interview at the end [SEP] I guess Scholastic is making the first book cheap in an attempt to get people into the whole series [SEP] I really liked the book a lot, but six more books seems like too much to read when I already have an extensive reading list [SEP] I'm glad I'm not into Harry Potter [SEP] It's little things like Komodo Dragon decorations coming to life, candle flames that don't flicker, and coins capable of screaming that make this book great [SEP] This is as imaginative as writing can get [SEP] I love it

imaginary fellows that spread a deadly plague, led by a guy with a sword of fire [SEP] Arthur doesn't know what to do to stop the plague, so he goes to a weird house only he can see [SEP] The book starts getting really fun at this point [SEP] We see people with angel wings, dinosaurs, an old guy with drilled out eyes, elevators of light, monsters with backwards faces who have one leg longer than the other, etc [SEP] Crazy stuff that'll keep you reading [SEP] Arthur finds out the only way he can stop the plague in his world is to defeat Mister Monday, and a ceramic frog guides him along in his journey [SEP] Going through the weird house to reach Mister Monday's dayroom isn't easy, but after many trials and some help from a girl named Suzy, Arthur manages to do so [SEP] Mister Monday's lazy personality completely changes when his authority is threatened, and after a violent confrontation, Arthur emerges victorious [SEP] With Mister Monday defeated, Arthur is able to go back home and cure the Fetcher plague [SEP] Then the build up to the second book promptly begins [SEP] It's very difficult to write in this "anything goes" style [SEP] No style is better at freeing up the imagination, but like everything else there is a price to pay [SEP] Usually when a work like this is loaded with imagination, continuity suffers as a result [SEP] I like to call this the "Pee-Wee's Playhouse Effect [SEP] "  Wonderful stuff constantly happens, but it's all disjointed, chaotic, and confusing [SEP] Personally, I don't mind the sacrifice of order a bit, especially in a book for children [SEP] My only comments are "Do we really need the Ed and Leaf characters?" and "Why's the guy in Ancient Greece speaking English?" This is the third $T$ I have read by Val McDermid [SEP] The first was, "A Place Of Execution", and it remains my favorite of the three [SEP] This newest offering, "Last Temptation", is a very good tale, but is definitely not for those readers who prefer to avoid the grisly details of murders, in this case those of a serial killer [SEP] There is also brutal violence with both men and women as victims, so read and be prepared [SEP] I don't find her descriptions to be gratuitous, just very graphic [SEP] He portrayals are probably much more accurate than generic description of violence that have become so prevalent and cliché that they are barely noticed [SEP] This author illustrates for the reader just how vile murder and violence are [SEP] This author uses atrocities committed by a group in the 20th century that I generally have tired of reading, as they have become the crutch for any form of evil [SEP] It is a tribute to this lady's talent that she has found a more obscure practice of the Germany of the Nazi's to play a very valid role in this $T$ [SEP] She also represents the evil of this group through the effects they have had on generations that were not even alive when they practiced their atrocities [SEP] Their twisted science echoes through the victims to their descendents, and this adds an entirely new dimension to the resonance of evil [SEP] The only aspect of the story I found troubling was the placement of the two main characters so close together while they were working on different operations [SEP] It makes the story work, but from the moment the situation is set, you know this is the Achilles heal that will bring the protagonists to the edge, or possibly over, to their detriment [SEP] I don't read many books in this type of genre, but Val McDermid seems as though her work should have a much greater following than it does [SEP] If this type of work appeals to you, pick this lady's work up; you will be happy you did

If you have any affection for $T$ and Carol Jordan as created by Val McDermid, don't read this book [SEP] I read "The Mermaids Singing" and was enthralled, but this one was a big disappointment [SEP] The plot involving the serial killer is shallow and seems tacked on [SEP] The real plot involves Carol, her relationship with Tony, and a sting operation that is completely unbelievable [SEP] The ending is a depressing let-down [SEP] Overall, the book is a big mess [SEP] Avoid it

$T$'s 'Mister Monday' was a highly clever, creative, and entertaining read that had me up into the wee hours of the morning following Arthur's adventures in the House [SEP] Arthur Penhaligon was a believable hero who after strange creatures called Fetchers bring a sleeply plague to his town, with his newly acquired key, Arthur must venture into the mysterious House that only he can see to save his town [SEP] Obviously, Nix wrote this book for a younger audience so his writing wasn't as [SEP] mature as it was in his brilliant Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] But the sheer imagination Nix brings to this book more than makes up for it [SEP] The intricate world of the House was highly entertaing and origional and Nix stuns me every time he writes a new story [SEP] 'Mister Monday' has everything a hugely popular series needs, loveable characters, a complex plot, and buckets loads of creativity [SEP] 'Grim Tuesday' is certainly going on my wish list!

This is probably the grittiest of the $T$/Carol Jordan stories and one of the best [SEP] Carol goes undercover in Europe to catch an international criminal and both she and Tony nearly lose their lives as a result [SEP] They both begin to acknowledge their feelings for each other but before it can go very far, events take over and in some ways, they end up even farther apart than they were before [SEP] This is not a story for the squeamish [SEP] There is quite a bit of brutal reality and a rape too terrible to even think about, but Val McDermid has created characters and a story that I just couldn't put down [SEP] It left me anxious to read the next book in the series

Its $T$'s first day at school and things aren't going so well [SEP] Arthur has really bad asthma, but since the new gym teacher doesn't know it, Arthur is forced to run [SEP] He doesn't want to appear stupid on the first day of school, so he decides to run even though he knows it could be really devasting to his health [SEP] And lone behold, Arthur has a severe asthma attack [SEP] However, just as he is about to die, he is handed a key shaped like a minute hand from a mysterious person called Mr [SEP] Monday who definitely doesn't belong in our world [SEP] Arthur survives, but soon his whole world is turned upside down [SEP] Mysterious dog faced animals are chasing after Arthur trying to get back the key, and they've brought a mysterious Sleeping Plague with them that could kill thousands, if not millions, since the doctors seem to have no cure at all [SEP] Soon Arthur realizes, that he, himself will have to venture into "The House", a house that only he can see, to save his world from utter destruction [SEP] It is in "The House" that Arthur makes friends with Suzy Turquoise Blue, and learns from "The Will" of his true destiny and has his final showdown with Mr [SEP] Monday [SEP] I had high expectations for Garth Nix's new series since I was an absolute fanatic over his Sabriel Trilogy and The Seventh Towers Series [SEP] After reading the first chapter of this book, I knew that I wouldn't be disappointed as it just sucks you in [SEP] I found this book to be more darker than Garth Nix's past stories, but you can definitely tell his unique writing style [SEP] His story structure carries over and you can pinpoint many similarties with this book and his other works [SEP] Arthur is a great protagonist, though he lacks the charm of Sabriel and Tal from Garth Nix's previous books [SEP] I definitely recommend reading this book, though I feel it is a touch lower than Garth Nix's Sabriel and Seventh Tower

A scientist in Seattle is missing after his family is murdered [SEP] A young $T$ goes missing from an Oregon resort town [SEP] A boyhood acquaintance, now an attorney, contacts Jack Whalen for help with a estate case that should have been open and shut - but isn't [SEP] Random incidents? Yes, unless you can connect the dots [SEP] Jack Whalen is a patrol cop who could have become a detective, but didn't [SEP] Instead he took cell phone photos of crime scenes where the perpetrator was an intruder [SEP] His simple descriptions of what it must have felt like to be invaded turns the pictures into a best-selling book [SEP] Now he and his wife have left Los Angeles for a remote town in Washington state [SEP] Jack's been working on another book, but is somehow blocked [SEP] His wife, Amy, goes to Seattle for a business meeting but never checks into the hotel [SEP] Jack goes to Seattle to find her and instead finds her cell phone abandoned in a cab and lots of questions--but no answers [SEP] And people are getting upset that he's even asking [SEP] Meanwhile Amy shows up at home and wonders why Jack is so upset [SEP] She has a simple explanation for everything, but Jack's cop instincts tell him all is not what it seems [SEP] The more threads he pulls, the more tangled things seem to get [SEP] And he's not sure anyone is really telling him the truth [SEP] And the truth is scarier than fiction [SEP] Marshall takes you on a roller coaster ride of emotions [SEP] Is Jack sane or losing his mind [SEP] Is he the only one seeing clearly - or is he delusional [SEP] What's behind these disappearances? One thing you know - Jack will get to the bottom of it all - or die trying [SEP] NOTE: Michael Marshall's alter ego is sci-fi and horror author Michael Marshall Smith [SEP] Armchair Interviews says: The Intruder is nominated for CWA Ian Fleming Steel Dagger Award

To me, this $T$ requires some imagination and patience [SEP] I could not just breeze through the Prologue and other parts of the $T$ without having to go back and reread some parts [SEP] But once I got into the beginning and reading about Arthur, the hesitant hero, the $T$ grew on me [SEP] I found it was quite easy to visualize the main character's adventures when he was on Earth in the beginning, but when the $T$ shifted to the other world [SEP] I kind of got confused again [SEP] But I did not give up reading the $T$ [SEP] I kept on, trying to visualize where Arthur was [SEP] The other world is quite original with its descriptions and the names given to different places, the characters, and so forth [SEP] I was kind of expecting Leaf to be with Arthur through the $T$ as a sidekick, but I liked Suzy just as well [SEP] I really like the quick adventure on the stairs and where it lead Suzy and Arthur [SEP] I was glad to find out where Suzy came from [SEP] I didn't even think about that until they reached the one platform [SEP] Mr [SEP] Monday was a funny, lazy villian (or rather a sleepy villian) [SEP] But I will say that Garth Nix is a very clever, talented writer [SEP] I liked how he made me think about what I was reading [SEP] It wasn't the kind of $T$, for me at least, where you can just read through and not pay attention [SEP] You have to pay attention to the writing because he eventually goes back to those details later on [SEP] There are connections, and I like a $T$ like that [SEP] So, in my opinion, if you read it, pay attention to the writing, be patient, and don't forget to add your imagination [SEP] Thanks

To me, this book requires some imagination and patience [SEP] I could not just breeze through the Prologue and other parts of the book without having to go back and reread some parts [SEP] But once I got into the beginning and reading about Arthur, the hesitant hero, the book grew on me [SEP] I found it was quite easy to visualize the main character's adventures when he was on Earth in the beginning, but when the book shifted to the other world [SEP] I kind of got confused again [SEP] But I did not give up reading the book [SEP] I kept on, trying to visualize where Arthur was [SEP] The other world is quite original with its descriptions and the names given to different places, the characters, and so forth [SEP] I was kind of expecting Leaf to be with Arthur through the book as a sidekick, but I liked Suzy just as well [SEP] I really like the quick adventure on the stairs and where it lead Suzy and Arthur [SEP] I was glad to find out where Suzy came from [SEP] I didn't even think about that until they reached the one platform [SEP] Mr [SEP] Monday was a funny, lazy villian (or rather a sleepy villian) [SEP] But I will say that $T$ is a very clever, talented writer [SEP] I liked how he made me think about what I was reading [SEP] It wasn't the kind of book, for me at least, where you can just read through and not pay attention [SEP] You have to pay attention to the writing because he eventually goes back to those details later on [SEP] There are connections, and I like a book like that [SEP] So, in my opinion, if you read it, pay attention to the writing, be patient, and don't forget to add your imagination [SEP] Thanks

$T$ is the first in a new series by Garth Nix, author of THE SEVENTH TOWER [SEP] Well paces and written for it's intended audience, younger readers, it weaves a spell binding story of reluctant heroes and less than evil villains [SEP] The young protagonist; Arthur Penhaligon, is chosen by the Will (the last instructions from the Great Architect, read God, before she takes off to places unknown,) to be the heir of the Keys to the Kingdom, to be the master of the House and the known universe [SEP] Problem is he's in the seventh grade and doesn't want to rule the world, all he wants to do is save his family and friends from a plague let lose by the same forces who don't want him to succeed, principally Mr [SEP] Monday, one of the seven trusties entrusted with the Will while GA is off gallivanting about [SEP] Although a lot of the characters, ok most of the characters, are rather bizarre the one that stands out in this sea of strangeness is Arthur [SEP] Throughout the story Arthur, even though given one of the keys to the universe, remains little more than a boy, a seventh grade boy [SEP] No superhero, no genius, just a boy who's forced to do something he really doesn't want to do [SEP] Written slightly below the level of the Harry Potter books this series should still capture the attention and imagination of young readers attracted to these types of stories [SEP] I found it to be a fun and enchanting read, maybe a little tame, but then I'm somewhat older than the target audience [SEP] I would certainly RECOMMEND this book to all the young readers out there, and even a few of the older ones

And lots of fun for the $T$ who refuses to grow up [SEP] Garth Nix has created a surprising world of fascinating characters and ideas [SEP] The plot moves right along and the young hero is likeable and delightfully normal [SEP] The book only occasionally does more telling than showing (mostly related to character emotions) but you'll hardly notice [SEP] It's one of the most inventive, Wonderland-adventures I've read in a long time [SEP] Counting the days until Grim Tuesday is released

If you don't already know it, this is $T$'s last case [SEP] I came across this book after I had read MANY other $T$'s cases and I was familiar with the surroundings [SEP] Lady Agatha takes us back to Styles Court, where we first met the little Belgian man with the egg shaped head [SEP] And so, the circle is closed [SEP] This is, in my opinion, the most mature of Christie's stories [SEP] $T$ faces the ultimate assassin: an individual capable of the perfect crime [SEP] He understands his methods, but also finds it impossible to intervene [SEP] And so he takes the matter on to his own hands, although knowing that no crime can go unpunished [SEP] Maybe the essence of the book is in the last few lines, hidden by a mark on a man's forehead [SEP] Don't miss it

If you are looking for a $T$, this is the book for you! This book is about an asmatic boy who has moved to a new school and the first day has a asma attack [SEP] In having this attach Arthur Penhaligon meets two new friends (Leaf and Ed twin brother and sister) and also gets a suprise, Mister Monday and his buttler, Sneezer, appear with a flash of light and give Arthur a gift,(Arthur thinks Sneezer is up to something but does not know) a minute hand of a clock (the clock that was guarding the will) and a book (An Atlas he can't yet open) [SEP] Arhtur does not know this but a will guarded by a clock face glass box and other odd things has been released which is the reason he got the key (clock hand) in the first place [SEP] During this book Arthur meets some odd people like some dog-faced men in bowler hats [SEP] At the beginning of the book he thought it was all a dream (from his asma attack) but he finds out that everything was very real [SEP] Arthur does not know the danger ahead of him untill the night somebody shows up at his window [SEP] This book is a wonderful choice [SEP] Garth Nix really outdid hiself when he wrote this one [SEP] This book reminds me of Ravens Gate in a way so if you read and liked it you will love this! One of the best books I have ever read [SEP] This is a dark side of the moon kind of book it is full of suspense and you never what will happen next [SEP] You will find yourself captivated by each letter in this book, you will see that you are swept away in the pages but don't want to come out! Mister Monday will do anything to get the key back (you will have to read to see if Arthur makes it through the book alive)!

One of the best books I have ever read [SEP] This is a dark side of the moon kind of book it is full of suspense and you never what will happen next [SEP] You will find yourself captivated by each letter in this book, you will see that you are swept away in the pages but don't want to come out! Mister Monday will do anything to get the key back (you will have to read to see if Arthur makes it through the book alive)!

$T$ and Sean seem to be a smooth and sophisticated senior high school couple [SEP] They introduce their awkward friends Maggie and Dennis to each other [SEP] Underneath the veneer of success $T$ and Sean have problems with their parents and each other [SEP] Do their parents understand or even care about them?  Are they ready for sex?  Meanwhile can Maggie and Dennis learn to communicate enough to stay together? [SEP] This book is Paul Zindel's second and was first published way back in 1969 [SEP] Life has changed since then, such as the free availability of legal abortion, but much of the story is still surprisingly relevant to modern life [SEP] $T$ and Maggie are the main characters so this could be described as a book for girls, but the lives of Sean and Dennis are also described in important sub-plots [SEP] The story is basically a double romance but Zindel has too much of a grip on the ugliness of life to describe the book as 'romantic [SEP] '  This is not Mills and Boon stuff [SEP] To tell the truth I find this novel one of Zindel's less successful works [SEP] To my mind there is nothing in the story to make it really memorable [SEP] But then again Zindel is so far above other writers that I would certainly still recommend reading the novel [SEP] I should also add that I am largely interested in coming of age stories about boys, so maybe I am biased

[SEP] This book is Paul Zindel's second and was first published way back in 1969 [SEP] Life has changed since then, such as the free availability of legal abortion, but much of the story is still surprisingly relevant to modern life [SEP] Liz and Maggie are the main characters so this could be described as a book for girls, but the lives of $T$ and Dennis are also described in important sub-plots [SEP] The story is basically a double romance but Zindel has too much of a grip on the ugliness of life to describe the book as 'romantic [SEP] '  This is not Mills and Boon stuff [SEP] To tell the truth I find this novel one of Zindel's less successful works [SEP] To my mind there is nothing in the story to make it really memorable [SEP] But then again Zindel is so far above other writers that I would certainly still recommend reading the novel [SEP] I should also add that I am largely interested in coming of age stories about boys, so maybe I am biased

I have always had a particular interest in children/teen fantasy [SEP] I normally am an adult fantasy reader, but sometimes it is nice to read a $T$ that isn't trying to play off like the real world [SEP] This $T$ is such a clever, compelling read that I was sorely disappointed to have to wait for more [SEP] I have never (so far) read a Garth Nix $T$ that doesn't re-inspire me to read more $T$s [SEP] Anyway, onto the actually $T$ itself [SEP] We are introduced to the typical male-boy protagonist, the awkward in school, unsure of himself protagonist with an incredible future [SEP] Arthur soon learns that his immediate problems are not the first day of school, but instead are the fact that he has to become the heir to the center of the universe [SEP] The entire idea of the House with different levels of work (mostly paperwork) is extremely creative [SEP] Everything about the environment and, we could say, culture of the House is a parody and play on real life [SEP] It is ironic that the nether-world still has to deal with paperwork and useless workers and bosses that could care less if what they are doing is right or not [SEP] The House also offers a sense of the extreme [SEP] Anything described inside usually is accompanied by ridiculous dimensions [SEP] For example any major room is about 40-50 football fields length or the job of filling a few hundred thousand ink bottles [SEP] It also offers a different version of the afterlife, as in it doesn't exist [SEP] The main reoccurring theme is "from nothing we came, and to nothing we return" a bit unsettling for the typical child [SEP] And that brings me to my next point [SEP] These $T$s are labeled, "Children Fantasy", but contains many references to myths and ideas that I believe are beyond a normal 9 year's old pool of knowledge [SEP] There are also a few really violent scenes that make me want to classify this more for Teens [SEP] Not that I am saying don't read this for the violence, just be warned if your a parent I recommend reading this ahead of time to make sure it'd be ok for your child (and really it only takes about a day or two to do) [SEP] In conclusion, this is a highly originally tale and I for one can't wait to read the other $T$s of this series [SEP] My only complaint is that Garth Nix takes about a year for every $T$ he writes and that's a long time to wait [SEP] But I guess if it makes the $T$s a masterpiece, it's a small sacrifice

books [SEP] Anyway, onto the actually book itself [SEP] We are introduced to the typical male-boy protagonist, the awkward in school, unsure of himself protagonist with an incredible future [SEP] Arthur soon learns that his immediate problems are not the first day of school, but instead are the fact that he has to become the heir to the center of the universe [SEP] The entire idea of the House with different levels of work (mostly paperwork) is extremely creative [SEP] Everything about the environment and, we could say, culture of the House is a parody and play on real life [SEP] It is ironic that the nether-world still has to deal with paperwork and useless workers and bosses that could care less if what they are doing is right or not [SEP] The House also offers a sense of the extreme [SEP] Anything described inside usually is accompanied by ridiculous dimensions [SEP] For example any major room is about 40-50 football fields length or the job of filling a few hundred thousand ink bottles [SEP] It also offers a different version of the afterlife, as in it doesn't exist [SEP] The main reoccurring theme is "from nothing we came, and to nothing we return" a bit unsettling for the typical child [SEP] And that brings me to my next point [SEP] These books are labeled, "Children Fantasy", but contains many references to myths and ideas that I believe are beyond a normal 9 year's old pool of knowledge [SEP] There are also a few really violent scenes that make me want to classify this more for Teens [SEP] Not that I am saying don't read this for the violence, just be warned if your a parent I recommend reading this ahead of time to make sure it'd be ok for your child (and really it only takes about a day or two to do) [SEP] In conclusion, this is a highly originally $T$ and I for one can't wait to read the other books of this series [SEP] My only complaint is that Garth Nix takes about a year for every book he writes and that's a long time to wait [SEP] But I guess if it makes the books a masterpiece, it's a small sacrifice

I'm wholeheartedly disappointed to see that some reviewers have perceived the $T$ to have a "chip on her shoulder" simply because she presents some facts on how society has perceived women who occupy the role of wife [SEP] This is a thought-provoking look at the history of how wives are perceived(and yes, let's take our blinders off people, because in one way or another, pop culture affects how we define ourselves, and it sure as heck is affecting our children!) [SEP] The research is original and fascinating [SEP] I am not opposed to marriage and hope to get married one day; furthermore, I was not at all offended by the tone of the book and did not feel that Kingston was trying to discourage anyone from getting married [SEP] Instead, she seems to challenge us to define ourselves beyond restrictive labels [SEP] For those who are moaning that the book lacks a thesis, I believe it lies in the proof that she gives over and over throughout the book: not all women are the same and to lump them all in one category (ie [SEP] "the vindictive other woman", "the helpless battered woman", "the sad, single girl with her cats", "the sassy single girl with her Manolo Blahniks", etc [SEP] ) has dangerous social consequences

The premise is simple enough; [SEP] young boy escapes his fate when it is revealed he is heir to unwelcome destiny [SEP] Enter $T$ [SEP] Arthur, upon whom the story centers, is definately your average selfish & dull little schoolboy, and when he has adventure thrust upon him it is most definately not welcome [SEP] When danger stares him in the face he reaches for his inhaler [SEP] When a journey beckons he steps behind someone else - all well played out themes for Nix newest hero [SEP] His world faced with plague & destruction, Arthur finds the courage to enter the unknown House and try to discover the origins of the mysterious key he was bequeathed, and which rather threatening characters are trying to take from him [SEP] Grim Monday's Noon is a wonderfully likable villian and his master, Mister Monday (after whom this first book is named)is a slothfully entertaining fellow, with his victorian clothing & die-away-airs [SEP] I would not say this book is strictly limited to a pre-teen audience, as I have found it to be very enjoyable [SEP] Upon entering $T$ Arthur discovers all sorts of oddities in what appears to be a parallel universe, and also meets up with The Old one, in what appears to be a play upon Prometheus shackled to the mountain [SEP] Which is interesting in ways which will be revealed once you read the book, remembering that "Prometheus" means "Forethought" [SEP] He also makes a friend, in Susie Turqouise Blue & we learn what really happend to the Pied Pipers children, and why it wasn't such a bad thing [SEP] To much information would give away the storyline, suffice to say Arthurs adventures will continue, this being the first of 7 [SEP] Seven days of the Week? [SEP] Arthur's last name is Penhaligon - another pun by the author on ruling the world & destiny? (kids look up the reference to King Arthur) [SEP] Nix makes some interesting speculations upon the origins of the universe [SEP] This is also very enjoyable as read by Allan Corduner, and is available from amazon [SEP] com in audio book format [SEP] kotori 2004

The premise is simple enough; [SEP] young boy escapes his fate when it is revealed he is heir to unwelcome destiny [SEP] Enter The House [SEP] Arthur, upon whom the story centers, is definately your average selfish & dull little schoolboy, and when he has adventure thrust upon him it is most definately not welcome [SEP] When danger stares him in the face he reaches for his inhaler [SEP] When a journey beckons he steps behind someone else - all well played out themes for Nix newest hero [SEP] His world faced with plague & destruction, Arthur finds the courage to enter the unknown House and try to discover the origins of the mysterious key he was bequeathed, and which rather threatening characters are trying to take from him [SEP] Grim Monday's Noon is a wonderfully likable villian and his master, Mister Monday (after whom this first book is named)is a slothfully entertaining fellow, with his victorian clothing & die-away-airs [SEP] I would not say this book is strictly limited to a pre-teen audience, as I have found it to be very enjoyable [SEP] Upon entering The House Arthur discovers all sorts of oddities in what appears to be a parallel universe, and also meets up with The Old one, in what appears to be a play upon Prometheus shackled to the mountain [SEP] Which is interesting in ways which will be revealed once you read the book, remembering that "Prometheus" means "Forethought" [SEP] He also makes a friend, in Susie Turqouise Blue & we learn what really happend to the Pied Pipers children, and why it wasn't such a bad thing [SEP] To much information would give away the storyline, suffice to say Arthurs adventures will continue, this being the first of 7 [SEP] Seven days of the Week? (kids look up the reference to King Arthur) [SEP] Nix makes some interesting speculations upon the origins of the universe [SEP] This is also very enjoyable as read by Allan Corduner, and is available from amazon [SEP] com in audio book format [SEP] kotori 2004

$T$ is about two sisters, one very angelic, and one very, very diabolic [SEP] The book starts out with Mrs [SEP] Cuthbertson-Jones, their mother, giving birth to the twins [SEP] Angela comes out very peacefully and doesn't cry afterwards, but Diabola comes out kicking and screaming and almost bites the nurse's finger off [SEP] The girls grow up into toddlers and Diabola becomes even worse while Angela became sweeter [SEP] When the twins are six they begin school [SEP] Angela is very excited, but Diabola is bored and gloomy [SEP] Then Diabola draws a horrid picture, and the principal thinks Diabola is a genius [SEP] Diabola then starts to love school, and especially drawing [SEP] The principal only starts to doubt that Diabola is a genius when she burns down the school building [SEP] After that Diabola starts acting even more diabolic [SEP] She acts so badly that Mr [SEP] Cuthbertson-Jones leaves and abandons his family [SEP] Diabola also discovers that she has powers where she can set things on fire, which is how she burned the school down [SEP] With these new powers, she burns her house down too [SEP] The Cuthbertson-Joneses have to move into a run down apartment [SEP] Diabola does many mean but funny things [SEP] Read the book and find out what she does!             I think this book is hilarious [SEP] It is also rather emotional at times, though, for instance when Angela encounters these weird feelings where she feels she must be near Diabola [SEP] My favorite part is when Diabola and Mrs [SEP] Cuthbertson-Jones are in the kitchen in their apartment and men come in and try to steal all their food [SEP] Diabola becomes mad and uses her powers to make their eyes sting [SEP] Mrs [SEP] Cuthbertson-Jones thinks Diabola hurt the men for her, but really Diabola didn't like the men and had done it for herself [SEP] My least favorite part is when Mr [SEP] Cuthbertson-Jones leaves his wife to handle the twins [SEP] A ngela becomes really emotional when her dad sends her letters [SEP]              I really liked this book and would recommend it to anyone who likes books about the good and the dark side of life [SEP] Anyone who likes Harry Potter would like this book because it is about fighting and neutralizing evil people [SEP] $T$ is a great book and I would recommend it to anyone who likes a funny novel

The children's novel "$T$" is a hardcore mix beetween mystery and science fiction [SEP] This is a 361 page book about a boy named Arthur Penhaligon who is destined to die an early death, but is saved by a key given to him by a mysterious man named Mister Monday [SEP] After being given the key he notices many strange things happening around his neighborhood [SEP] Including a strange house a few blocks away from his house [SEP] he journeys up the house into Mister Monday's room on the top floor of the house [SEP] After Arthur defeats Mister Monday he surrenders his strange powers to "The Will" [SEP] I liked the way the author described all imnportant and  non-important characters in such detail, but I didn't like the way he kept coming back to the question "why did Arthur get the key, why is he still alive, who are Mister Monday and Sneezer" [SEP] My favorite character in this book was Noon the first big Villain or henchman of Mister Monday [SEP] He is my favorite character because he has and awesome outfit, I mean there aren't many guys waliking around with wings and a flaming sword [SEP] My favorite secton or scene was when mister monday & Sneezer first appeared [SEP] I liked the way the author made it so i could picture it in my head [SEP] What i would say to someone about this book is about a nobody kid who ends up saving the world [SEP] One question I have is what happens after you fall asleep during the process of the "Sleepy Plague" [SEP] I would strongely recommend this book for someone who likes a book in which they can picture all of the important moments

In 1750, Scotland emerged from half a century of civil strife [SEP] Its parliament was subsumed by Westminster, and the English were vigilant for any sign of Jacobite rebellion [SEP] Despite this, Scotland was at the beginning of a period of resurgence that was to last two centuries [SEP] This fascinating look at of the Golden Age of Scottish history includes: the great names of the “$T$,” including Adam Smith and David Hume; writers, such as Robert Burns, Walter Scott, and Robert Louis Stevenson; scientists and inventors, among them Watson and Watt; as well as engineers of the Empire; missionaries and explorers; and pioneers of surgery and medicine [SEP] An illuminating account of the outstanding achievements of this proud nation [SEP]

If there is any tool of education which highlights our $T$, it is this book [SEP] I am sure Paul Zindel means well, but his outlook on human life is simplistic at best and cynical at worst [SEP] The man clearly believes humanity is a small step above animals, and that our children should be raised to accept their fate in this Ricki Lake world in which we live [SEP] This is the sort of book that turns children into sex and relationship obsessed creatures, consumed with nothing but the desire to eat and procreate [SEP] It is for those who desire nothing more than to live like cattle, with some improved diversion courtesy other human inventors (ie television) [SEP] What is even worse is reading the reviews of this book [SEP] Wow

I could not put $T$'s latest down [SEP] He's created a multi-layered thriller involving a likeable protagonist plus a host of remarkable satellite characters who make you cringe & groan with curiosity & anticipation [SEP] Set in the Pacific Northwest, the prologue of THE INTRUDERS starts with an apparently random home invasion, murder & fire [SEP] Then we meet Jack Whalen, ex-LA beat cop & a one-book author who's struggling to write another [SEP] Instead, he's sitting staring out at the forested panorama & remembering, for some odd reason, a high school classmate & how she didn't quite fit in & who, after trying to get the attention of the handsomest senior jock, committed suicide [SEP] That morning, Jack's wife had driven to Seattle for a meeting at her ad agency [SEP] That's why, a couple of years ago, they'd moved up to this idyllic little mountain burg on the eastside of the Cascades from Southern California, where they'd met & married ten years before [SEP] Then that very same jock, now 20 years older, calls Jack, wanting to see him [SEP] Gary Fisher brings a strange tale and Jack, with his beat cop instincts slowly coming alert, senses his visitor isn't telling him everything & some of what he's said doesn't ring true [SEP] But Jack has no time for Gary as he's just discovered his wife's cell phone has been found in a Seattle taxi [SEP] On Cannon Beach in Oregon, a nine year old girl is struggling with nightmares, her parents' uneasy marriage, & something far more frightening: loss of memory & the arrival of a stranger as she's out on the beach wondering how she got there [SEP] When the idea that she's got to go somewhere sets her traveling, the people who help her along the way come to rue it as this nice, little girl with headaches has a killer's instincts [SEP] THE INTRUDERS is a tale well-spun with lashings of deceit & determination, action & clues, body & mind invasions & chases, & other scary stuff [SEP] It's a thriller that has you connecting dots like mad, except, are you connecting the right ones? Unto the final page, you won't know!

Oregon, a nine year old girl is struggling with nightmares, her parents' uneasy marriage, & something far more frightening: loss of memory & the arrival of a stranger as she's out on the beach wondering how she got there [SEP] When the idea that she's got to go somewhere sets her traveling, the people who help her along the way come to rue it as this nice, little girl with headaches has a killer's instincts [SEP] THE INTRUDERS is a $T$ well-spun with lashings of deceit & determination, action & clues, body & mind invasions & chases, & other scary stuff [SEP] It's a thriller that has you connecting dots like mad, except, are you connecting the right ones? Unto the final page, you won't know!

I could not put Michael Marshall's latest down [SEP] He's created a multi-layered $T$ involving a likeable protagonist plus a host of remarkable satellite characters who make you cringe & groan with curiosity & anticipation [SEP] Set in the Pacific Northwest, the prologue of THE INTRUDERS starts with an apparently random home invasion, murder & fire [SEP] Then we meet Jack Whalen, ex-LA beat cop & a one-book author who's struggling to write another [SEP] Instead, he's sitting staring out at the forested panorama & remembering, for some odd reason, a high school classmate & how she didn't quite fit in & who, after trying to get the attention of the handsomest senior jock, committed suicide [SEP] That morning, Jack's wife had driven to Seattle for a meeting at her ad agency [SEP] That's why, a couple of years ago, they'd moved up to this idyllic little mountain burg on the eastside of the Cascades from Southern California, where they'd met & married ten years before [SEP] Then that very same jock, now 20 years older, calls Jack, wanting to see him [SEP] Gary Fisher brings a strange tale and Jack, with his beat cop instincts slowly coming alert, senses his visitor isn't telling him everything & some of what he's said doesn't ring true [SEP] But Jack has no time for Gary as he's just discovered his wife's cell phone has been found in a Seattle taxi [SEP] On Cannon Beach in $T$, only 13, survives what is supposed to be his death on his first day at a new school when he is handed a key shaped like the minute hand on a clock by the elusive Mister Monday [SEP] This key enables him to fight off the dog-faced Fetchers that are searching his school for him, and then get into the mysterious House he alone seems to be able to see in order to find a cure for the Sleepy Plague the Fetchers seem to have started [SEP] Once inside the house, he finds obstacles, a friend to help him, and a fragment of the Will which states how everything should be run in the house and the Secondary Realms, in which his house is [SEP] The Will gives him instructions on how to get the Greater Key (shaped like the hour hand on a clock) from Mister Monday and become Master of the Lower House [SEP] Garth Nix has woven another intricate fantasy tale including wonderfully believable characters, strange creatures, and a tendency for the unexpected [SEP] His series including Sabriel, Lirael, and Abhorsen left me wanting more of his work, and I have not been disappointed by this new tale of his [SEP] I am going to quickly get the second book and then impatiently await the next five

Rating System: [SEP] 1 star = abysmal; some books deserve to be forgotten [SEP] 2 star = poor; a total waste of time [SEP] 3 star = good; worth the effort [SEP] 4 star = very good; what writing should be [SEP] 5 star = fantastic; must own it and share it with others [SEP] THE STORY: [SEP] $T$ is a boy weakened by asthma and in having to live in the shadow of a very successful family [SEP] His normal life of interrupting his family's lives because they have to rush him to the hospital due to asthma attacks changes when he finds himself the chosen heir to the House [SEP] Arthur with the lesser key to the lower kingdom of the House in hand, must travel into the House to find a cure for the mysterious plague that is striking the people of his town and his loved ones and find out why there are beings intent on getting the key from him, even if it means killing him [SEP] THE GOOD: [SEP] Garth Nix is becoming one of my favorite authors of all time [SEP] His fantasy works are not cliché or based on traditional fantasy but they are full of fresh, imagination and worlds and characters we can learn to love [SEP] I got hooked on this author after reading Sabriel, which is a fantasy about necromancer magic [SEP] Very cool! So when I saw he had a new series out I had to check it out and was not disappointed [SEP] 1) Great world creation in the House and the denizens of the House, their purpose, their origins, etc [SEP] Made for an interesting and unique setting [SEP] 2) Likeable characters that are led by the plot of the story, where options are reduced forcing the protagonists down certain routes but without the reader knowing what those results those routes will produce, per se [SEP] Kept the plot and characters engaging and fun to read [SEP] 3) Magic [SEP] Unique and fun and innovative [SEP] Loved everything about it! [SEP] 4) 98% of all storylines and subplots resolved in this single volume [SEP] Chapters had great cliff hangers and transition points to keep the reader turning and the end of the book has its own cliff hanger that makes us want to read the next book in the series though it isn't necessary [SEP] 5) As much as the storylines are resolved, the resolution was also satisfactory and didn't make me feel cheated or the author tried too hard or too little to provide a satisfying ending [SEP] THE BAD: [SEP] I don't have anything that comes to mind other than this wasn't a hugely character driven story but more plot driven and setting driven in my mind [SEP] To get more in the characters and their motivations would have been a plus but because the story focus is on the discovery of the House and things related to the House, I didn't expect to get into the characters more than we did and thus I really wasn't too disappointed [SEP] OVERALL: [SEP] I left with the feeling of having been in a fairy tale [SEP] This would make a GREAT movie in my opinion [SEP] Read Garth Nix for unique and engaging fantasy [SEP] Either read the Abhorsen Trilogy for more of an adult fantasy, where the main protagonist is 17-18 yrs of age [SEP] Read this series for a protagonist that is around 12 yrs of age and the scenes are less "dark" than the Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] Either way, both stories are a big win

[SEP] 4) 98% of all storylines and subplots resolved in this single volume [SEP] Chapters had great cliff hangers and transition points to keep the reader turning and the end of the book has its own cliff hanger that makes us want to read the next book in the series though it isn't necessary [SEP] 5) As much as the storylines are resolved, the resolution was also satisfactory and didn't make me feel cheated or the author tried too hard or too little to provide a satisfying ending [SEP] THE BAD: [SEP] I don't have anything that comes to mind other than this wasn't a hugely character driven story but more plot driven and setting driven in my mind [SEP] To get more in the characters and their motivations would have been a plus but because the story focus is on the discovery of the House and things related to the House, I didn't expect to get into the characters more than we did and thus I really wasn't too disappointed [SEP] OVERALL: [SEP] I left with the feeling of having been in a fairy tale [SEP] This would make a GREAT movie in my opinion [SEP] Read Garth Nix for unique and engaging fantasy [SEP] Either read the Abhorsen Trilogy for more of an adult fantasy, where the main protagonist is 17-18 yrs of age [SEP] Read this series for a protagonist that is around 12 yrs of age and the scenes are less "dark" than the Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] Either way, both stories are a big win

Rating System: [SEP] 1 star = abysmal; some books deserve to be forgotten [SEP] 2 star = poor; a total waste of time [SEP] 3 star = good; worth the effort [SEP] 4 star = very good; what writing should be [SEP] 5 star = fantastic; must own it and share it with others [SEP] THE STORY: [SEP] $T$ Penhaligon is a boy weakened by asthma and in having to live in the shadow of a very successful family [SEP] His normal life of interrupting his family's lives because they have to rush him to the hospital due to asthma attacks changes when he finds himself the chosen heir to the House [SEP] $T$ with the lesser key to the lower kingdom of the House in hand, must travel into the House to find a cure for the mysterious plague that is striking the people of his town and his loved ones and find out why there are beings intent on getting the key from him, even if it means killing him [SEP] THE GOOD: [SEP] Garth Nix is becoming one of my favorite authors of all time [SEP] His fantasy works are not cliché or based on traditional fantasy but they are full of fresh, imagination and worlds and characters we can learn to love [SEP] I got hooked on this author after reading Sabriel, which is a fantasy about necromancer magic [SEP] Very cool! So when I saw he had a new series out I had to check it out and was not disappointed [SEP] 1) Great world creation in the House and the denizens of the House, their purpose, their origins, etc [SEP] Made for an interesting and unique setting [SEP] 2) Likeable characters that are led by the plot of the story, where options are reduced forcing the protagonists down certain routes but without the reader knowing what those results those routes will produce, per se [SEP] Kept the plot and characters engaging and fun to read [SEP] 3) Magic [SEP] Unique and fun and innovative [SEP] Loved everything about it! [SEP] 4) 98% of all storylines and subplots resolved in this single volume [SEP] Chapters had great cliff hangers and transition points to keep the reader turning and the end of the book has its own cliff hanger that makes us want to read the next book in the series though it isn't necessary [SEP] 5) As much as the storylines are resolved, the resolution was also satisfactory and didn't make me feel cheated or the author tried too hard or too little to provide a satisfying ending [SEP] THE BAD: [SEP] I don't have anything that comes to mind other than this wasn't a hugely character driven story but more plot driven and setting driven in my mind [SEP] To get more in the characters and their motivations would have been a plus but because the story focus is on the discovery of the House and things related to the House, I didn't expect to get into the characters more than we did and thus I really wasn't too disappointed [SEP] OVERALL: [SEP] I left with the feeling of having been in a fairy tale [SEP] This would make a GREAT movie in my opinion [SEP] Read Garth Nix for unique and engaging fantasy [SEP] Either read the Abhorsen Trilogy for more of an adult fantasy, where the main protagonist is 17-18 yrs of age [SEP] Read this series for a protagonist that is around 12 yrs of age and the scenes are less "dark" than the Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] Either way, both stories are a big win

So when I saw he had a new series out I had to check it out and was not disappointed [SEP] 1) Great world creation in the House and the denizens of the House, their purpose, their origins, etc [SEP] Made for an interesting and unique setting [SEP] 2) Likeable $T$ that are led by the plot of the story, where options are reduced forcing the protagonists down certain routes but without the reader knowing what those results those routes will produce, per se [SEP] Kept the plot and $T$ engaging and fun to read [SEP] 3) Magic [SEP] Unique and fun and innovative [SEP] Loved everything about it! [SEP] 4) 98% of all storylines and subplots resolved in this single volume [SEP] Chapters had great cliff hangers and transition points to keep the reader turning and the end of the book has its own cliff hanger that makes us want to read the next book in the series though it isn't necessary [SEP] 5) As much as the storylines are resolved, the resolution was also satisfactory and didn't make me feel cheated or the author tried too hard or too little to provide a satisfying ending [SEP] THE BAD: [SEP] I don't have anything that comes to mind other than this wasn't a hugely character driven story but more plot driven and setting driven in my mind [SEP] To get more in the $T$ and their motivations would have been a plus but because the story focus is on the discovery of the House and things related to the House, I didn't expect to get into the $T$ more than we did and thus I really wasn't too disappointed [SEP] OVERALL: [SEP] I left with the feeling of having been in a fairy tale [SEP] This would make a GREAT movie in my opinion [SEP] Read Garth Nix for unique and engaging fantasy [SEP] Either read the Abhorsen Trilogy for more of an adult fantasy, where the main protagonist is 17-18 yrs of age [SEP] Read this series for a protagonist that is around 12 yrs of age and the scenes are less "dark" than the Abhorsen trilogy [SEP] Either way, both stories are a big win
