Read this $T$ to find out

$T$'s book begins with a description of Prince Charles' and Princess Di's wedding and sort of stays there [SEP] She spends a great deal of time focusing on the upper classes, whether royalty, celebrities, politicians or CEOs [SEP] Ignored, or perhaps forgotten, are those whose weddings cost less than $50,000, who do not have a choice about working or staying home, who get married at City Hall, and who cannot squeeze every dime out of the ex--because he doesn't have that much more himself [SEP] Ignored also are issues such as the effect of parenthood on a marriage, same-sex marriages (even lesbians do laundry), and the role that religion has played in marriage [SEP] $T$'s book not only focuses on the upper echelons, but the most extreme marraiges [SEP] Her chapter on divorce, for example, portrays women who just about break the law getting back at their ex-husbands [SEP] If you are an average woman who took two weeks off her job for her honeymoon, pick something else

I am a big fan of $T$ and really enjoyed his "Abhorsen" series [SEP] Then I heard that this series came out and that it was getting really good reviews, so I checked it out of the library [SEP] It was as good as promised [SEP] The whole plot is very interesting and loaded with symbolism [SEP] It is about Arthur, an average boy who turns into an extraordinary boy [SEP] The character development is very good for the supporting characters like Suzy Blue and the Will, but not so good for Arthur himself [SEP] ANyway, the book was action packed and very fast paced [SEP] It is the first of a seven-part series (one for each day of the week) [SEP] The other three that are out by now are equally good, but the whole series is VERY fast-paced [SEP] I really enjoy this series, and I can't wait for the Friday to come [SEP] Meanwhile, I will reread the last four to pick up all the little symbols and clues that Nix casually scatters through the story

Ahh [SEP] I wish I had never gotten this stupid key, it is the kiss of death, and has ruined my life [SEP] This thought races through $T$'s mind as he saves the world in Mister Monday [SEP] $T$ is put through a rigorous test of bravery and compassion to face the evil Mister Monday [SEP] In the story, $T$ receives a key that gives him the power he needs to defeat Mister Monday, the only problem is, he doesn't know whom Monday is, or anything about the strange world that Monday lives in [SEP] $T$ has to go to a foreign realm and defeat an enemy that has so much more power than he does, if Monday was a T-Rex then $T$ would be a blade of grass compared to him [SEP] $T$'s battle to save earth requires a level of bravery that he only imagines in his dreams [SEP] That is why the theme is bravery, $T$ has to summon a level of bravery that he can't, and through the story, he struggles to get this unknown bravery [SEP] $T$ ventures through the story finding the bravery he needs [SEP] Mister Monday is a phenomenal book that gets an excellent 10/10 [SEP] This book wraps you up in the story; it sucks you into the pages like a black hole [SEP] You are transported through a mystical land that gets better as you proceed [SEP] That's why Mister Monday is so irresistible, and it's a great book not only for fantasy readers, but also for anyone looking for a great story

$T$ is an interesting Fantasy novel that draws readers in from the very beginning [SEP] The main character, Arthur is flawed and that is what makes him the "chosen" one for the Keys to the Kingdom [SEP] In this series starter, Arthur learns what power he has as he tries to determine how to live his life with this key that he has obtained and this house and little, scary fantasy creatures that no one else can see but him [SEP] Arthur starts to think he is losing it, but a few friends from his P [SEP] E [SEP] class see the creatures too, so Arthur apprehensively goes on his journey as the reluctant hero who is bound to find a way to save his community and family [SEP] This book along with Grim Tuesday will hook readers on this series [SEP] I can't wait for the rest of the books in this series [SEP] Harry Potter lovers can definitely find a new love in this series

$T$ is a top-class crime writer - she rarely fails to deliver and I am pleased to say, this book is great [SEP] Dr Tony Hill and DCI Jordan are back - hurrah!  Tony Hill is the profiler who has retired to a backwater university to lick his wounds after the traumatising experiences he has suffered in the past [SEP] He is drawn back to the fray when his old love interest, DCI Jordan, becomes involved in a dangerous undercover mission in Eastern Europe [SEP] Running parallel to this is a creepy serial killer who Tony Hill tries to find and unmask [SEP] It is a very entertaining novel and all fans of McDermid will relish it

I really enjoyed Sabriel [SEP] To a lesser degree, I was also fond of the other books in the The Abhorsen Trilogy [SEP] When I was in the mood for some YA fantasy the other week, I immediately turned to Mr [SEP] Monday [SEP] And it was a pretty good $T$ [SEP] Arthur Penhaligon is a classic YA hero-- asthmatic, smart, and non-conformist [SEP] The world that he lives in is similar to ours, but different enough to be intriguing [SEP] The keys and Mr [SEP] Monday are intriguing concepts [SEP] The alternative world is a little bit complicated, but I like complicated [SEP] Bureaucracy plus the pied piper plus disorganized destiny plus raggedy-wing angels-- lots of stuff to sink your teeth into [SEP] My biggest beef has nothing to do with the story [SEP] My brand new HarperCollins edition is missing pages 351 to 401 [SEP] Instead, they bound pages 257-304 where the other pages should have been [SEP] That means that I missed the climactic confrontation with Mr [SEP] Monday [SEP] Very irritating [SEP] I have no idea if it was only my book with this problem [SEP] Potential buyers should check to make sure that they have all the pages before it is too late to return the book [SEP] I'll definitely $T$ Grim Tuesday, in any case

In her book A History of the Wife, Marilyn Yalom traces the history and changing roles women have had in marriage from early history through the women's liberation movement [SEP] The $T$ picks up where that excellent book ends [SEP] It is clear from the cover of this book (a woman's left hand, flipping off the reader-with a perfectly manicured and wedding band-clad ring finger) that this is a book for a generation of women who are both used to confrontation and longing for tradition [SEP] It is this dichotomy in their lives that fuels the book [SEP] As women are working outside the home more, demanding more equitable treatment, and becoming market forces, they are also struggling to define what being a wife actually means to them [SEP] Kingston examines that many facets of wifeliness that seem to prevail: helpmeet, virgin, Cinderella (equally entranced by the wedding dress as she is of scented toilet bowl cleaner), victim of abuse, shrew, spinster (or unwife), or supporting actress [SEP] The main struggle for women now isn't whether or not to get married [SEP] Kingston is no Steinem and doesn't suggest that a woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle (though she is unmarried) [SEP] She acknowledges that women want to be wives and mothers [SEP] The problem is that they don't have role models [SEP] They have seen their mothers struggle to get out of the kitchen and are in no great rush to get back into it [SEP] Their icons growing up on TV were single women, Superwomen who could do it all by themselves [SEP] Popular culture, in the form of advertising, movies, books, news media, and television, is the most common source of clues to how women seek to describe themselves [SEP] Their icons now are very different [SEP] They see the brides, the yearning for marriage and a fairy tale wedding [SEP] Kingston excels and describing the marketing behind this notion (and I love that this industry now has an insidious name: the wedding industrial complex) [SEP] But once the marriage happens, there are a few very different ideas of what a married woman is [SEP] They see the happy homemaker [SEP] Though most have absolutely no desire to be homemakers, they still feel the pressure to have a well-kept home [SEP] A certain amount of bliss is marketed along with cleaning products [SEP] Or they are seen as the victim of love-the battered wife (an excellent chapter on the presentation of domestic abuse is given, including how it both infantilizes women and takes them back to Victorian times when women were seen to only follow their wombs, rather than brains, in decision making) [SEP] The main theme of this book is that there is not and cannot be one script for how to be a wife, just as there is no one role for husband [SEP] This is a well-written, researched, and balanced look at what marriage means now, not just wife [SEP] It isn't a reactionary or staunchly second-wave feminist look at marriage; Kingston respects marriage and the desire to be married [SEP] Excellent to read alongside A History of the Wife, The Mommy Myth: The Idealization of Motherhood and How It Has Undermined All Womenand Selling Anxiety: How the News Media Scare Women

the kitchen and are in no great rush to get back into it [SEP] Their icons growing up on TV were single women, Superwomen who could do it all by themselves [SEP] Popular culture, in the form of industrial complex) [SEP] But once the marriage happens, there are a few very different ideas of what a married woman is [SEP] They see the happy homemaker [SEP] Though most have absolutely no desire to be homemakers, they still feel the pressure to have a well-kept home [SEP] A certain amount of bliss is marketed along with cleaning products [SEP] Or they are seen as the victim of love-the battered wife (an excellent chapter on the presentation of domestic abuse is given, including how it both infantilizes women and takes them back to Victorian times when women were seen to only follow their wombs, rather than brains, in decision making) [SEP] The main theme of this book is that there is not and cannot be one script for how to be a wife, just as there is no one role for $T$ [SEP] How the News Media Scare Women

This is a $T$, but it is so much more [SEP] It's an insight into the law enforcement agencies across Europe and an undercover police operation all rolled into one [SEP] We see the return of criminal psychologist Tony Hill and Carol Jordan a police officer who has just applied for a job with Europol, working behind a desk processing information [SEP] But her superiors see her as something more and offer her a job working undercover [SEP] Through this undercover work, she and Tony Hill renew their acquaintance and begin chasing down a German criminal named Tadeusz Radecki [SEP] He has recently branched out from his drug distribution into people smuggling [SEP] Also chasing down Radecki is Petra Becker, a criminal intelligence officer in Berlin who has been after him for years and is hot on his trail after the murder of a drug dealer [SEP] She corresponds to a friend in Holland over the Internet and occasionally helps out when it comes to solving crimes [SEP] In this case, there is a serial killer on the loose across Europe who seems to be targeting psychologists by replicating atrocities performed during the reign of the Nazi's in Germany [SEP] Although spread across Europe and seemingly tenuously linked, the whole story is nicely drawn together [SEP] It's a book that would best be classed as a shocker with some descriptive, grisly scenes [SEP] We are also treated to the killer's thoughts and the reasons behind his motives, suggesting that there are still more victims of the medical experiments performed during World War 2 than those who died [SEP] Val McDermid has once again produced an exciting and entertaining thriller [SEP] Fans of the psychological suspense novels will find this one right up their alley

If you are looking for a $T$ forget it [SEP] The $T$ is secondary to the rest of the story and is only really approached in the remaining 30 pages of the book [SEP] I found "Skylar" to be a better book, because the story was more original [SEP] As mentioned by one of the previous reviews that story centers around Jonathan Whitfield a "yankee" being the fish out of water around his cousin Skylar's southern surroundings [SEP] It seems this book was written just for the heck of it to see what it would be like to have Skylar up north [SEP] In "Skylar" we learn that the dumb hick image that Skylar puts on is all a facade and that he is truly a clever person [SEP] This story while showing glimpses of his intelligence disappointingly reverts to this original perception and it feels like you are reading the same story again [SEP] If you are interested in reading a Gregory MacDonald book then read one of the earlier Fletch novels [SEP] They don't actually read like the Chevy Chase movies but they are witty and worth the time (with the occasional weak book in the mix) [SEP] If you have already read all the Fletch stories then you can give "Skylar" a try, but don't expect it to be on par with them [SEP] I would recommend the Flynn stories: "The Buck Passes Flynn","Flynn", & "Flynn's In" (about a boston detective/government agent) [SEP] You may not be able to order them but you can be sure to find them in a used book store, and they are definitely more worth while than the Skylar books

$T$ is the first of a two-book series (the second is:  A Spy at Twilight) in the vein of the Le Carre "Karla" quartet [SEP] Mr [SEP] Forbes also played his part in that "game" and writes with  considerable authority [SEP] The book is well-crafted and grips you as you work  through the developing enigma and misleading clues with the protagonist [SEP] The characters are complex and believable, the plot consistent and the  outcome unguessable until the last pages [SEP] Altogether, a most satisfying  read for lovers of spy fiction

Other reviewers have mentioned the Potter series, but this book reminded me more of Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy [SEP] As in HDM, the world is bleak, the heroes are young and most adults seem oblivious to anyone else, except as they may be used in some grandiose scheme [SEP] Unlike with HDM, I couldn't develop any integrated picture of the KTTK world [SEP] Things were described, but the descriptions seemed like prop lists [SEP] The $T$ seemed capable of throwing in anything or anyone that we might have read about elsewhere [SEP] For example, Prometheus shows up - with a different name [SEP] At times, I felt like I was reading a screenplay, "Hey, this'll look great in the film, (coming soon to a theater near you) and they probably have some on the backlot!"  Maybe I should have called this 'Will and Dr [SEP] Who vs [SEP] Screwtape [SEP] '  I did want to find out how it turned out, so despite all criticisms, I think it probably works for the early teenager that hasn't already read everything in the genre

I really enjoy $T$'s writing style, and heartily recommend one of his earlier novels, THE STRAW MEN [SEP] But THE INTRUDERS is pretty much a middling effort, at least when it comes to the plot [SEP] The first half of this novel is certainly well written, but the plotline is disjointed and makes little sense [SEP] Smith keeps on shifting perspectives and deliberately keeps the reader off-balance [SEP] While some readers may enjoy this type of storytelling, I prefer novels with straightforward narratives [SEP] Smith tries to tie everything together toward the end, but his "explanation" is so silly and contrived that I felt cheated [SEP] In the end, I felt the whole story was pointless [SEP] THE INTRUDERS is further weakened by the lack of a truly likable character [SEP] While all the characters are intelligent, most of them are dour and anti-social [SEP] There are also too many characters to keep track of, and some of them are just stereotypical (the world-weary hit man for example) [SEP] Still, Smith is a terrific writer of prose, one of the best out there in genre fiction [SEP] There are many passages in thsi novel that I re-read because I was struck by their cleverness and insight [SEP] I recommend THE INTRUDERS if you enjoy good writing, but if you want a great story, you should try THE STRAW MEN instead

In this book, $T$ uses the psychoanalytic movement as a "case study" to explore the general human tendency to create delusional ideological systems which serve various political, social, and psychological needs [SEP] He also focuses in on the specific structural features of modern life that made psychoanalysis an especially successful ideology [SEP] As Gellner sums up in his final chapter, "In a sense, the present book is more interested in our Zeitgeist than in psychoanalysis [SEP] The crucial strategic position occupied by Freudianism in the social and intellectual history of mankind, makes it possible for us to learn a vast amount from it about, on the one hand, the general anatomy of belief systems and, on the other, the special conditions prevalent in our age [SEP] " [SEP] In his first two chapters, Gellner focuses in on what might be called the modern predicament [SEP] Before the rise of natural science and philosophical empiricism, it was easy to explain the mixture of good and evil, the sheer perversity, embodied in human beings [SEP] Humans were, quite literally, halfway between beasts and angels [SEP] The rise of science and modern philosophy invalidated that belief [SEP] Taking David Hume as a prime example, Gellner shows that the scientific, empiricist thought of the Enlightenment abandoned the angel/beast dichotomy [SEP] The Enlightenment theorists naturalized man: the model of man they ended up with, which Gellner dubs the "Bundleman," was a random mixture of self-interested desires and needs which were easily satisfied by a conservatively cautious policy of maximizing pleasure and minimizing pain [SEP] Real human beings, of course, act much more like a mixture of angel and beast than the cautiously and rationally selfish "Bundleman" of the Enlightenment [SEP] Nietzsche was, Gellner claims, the first serious post-Enlightenment thinker to fully realize this fact, and the realization finally drove poor Nietzsche insane [SEP] Freud's genius was to take the Nietzschean insight and domesticate it, thereby turning it into the basis of a very successful, very lucrative pseudo-scientific cult - psychoanalysis [SEP] Freud's task was made easier by certain features of the modern world [SEP] The modern world exhibits deep reverence for applied science, especially medicine [SEP] In modern industrial societies, technology has eradicated most traditional physical threats (starvation, plague, wild animals, etc [SEP] ) [SEP] In our society, the pressing threats perceived by most people lie rather in the increasing complexity of, and importance placed upon, human relationships [SEP] It is just in this area of interpersonal relationships where psychoanalysis offered help [SEP] Most of the book explores the tricks and turns by which psychoanalysis maintained its authority [SEP] Nowadays, now that there is hardly an intelligent person left who is a hard-core believer in the Freudian faith, is this of any more than historical interest? [SEP] Yes [SEP] While Freud may finally be buried, his residue endures -- as "therapy," "couselling," "adjustment," etc [SEP] -- and continues to muddle our thinking process and our ability to make moral evaluations [SEP] As Gellner rhetorically asks, concerning the Holy Grail of "adjustment," "[I]s adaptation, adjustment to any regime, including a tyrannical one, a sign of mental health?"  The Soviets, hardly orthodox Freudians, famously answered "Yes!" [SEP] But even more important, as Gellner emphasizes, the fraud of Freudianism is a typical example of the functioning of human society in general: [SEP] "Societies possess techniques for rendering ideas socially constitutive, and these techniques tend to share certain formal features [SEP] It is important to remember that this is the normal condition of mankind: most ideas of most men at most times are beyond the reach of questioning [SEP] An idea does not have simply a cognitive role [SEP] it is at the same time linked to a set of personal relations, to loyalties, hierarchies, sentiments, hopes and fears [SEP] To shake the idea would be to disturb all that [SEP] Most men are neither willing nor able to do that [SEP] " [SEP] To put it more bluntly, the structure of all hitherto existing human societies is grounded in socially-imposed, emotionally-compelling lies [SEP] Did Freud and his colleagues engage in bizarre intellectual contortions to prevent their ideas from being questioned or subjected to criticism? [SEP] Yes [SEP] but have you ever asked a liberal why we must slavishly accede to the results of a democratic election?  The answer is that if you choose to vote, you are obliged to accept the results, and, if you don't vote, you have no right to complain [SEP] Is Freudian reasoning any more circular than that? [SEP] Did Freud and his colleagues frantically avoid confronting their theories with empirical reality?  (Freud once declared that "I cannot advise too strongly against" seeking out empirical evidence to check the conclusions of a psychoanalytic diagnosis because the result would be that "confidence in the analysis is shattered and a court of appeal is set up over it [SEP] ") [SEP] Yes [SEP] but have you ever talked with a conservative about the actual historical process by which the US Constitution was "ratified"? [SEP] Do Freudians apply different standards to themselves than to all other human beings, accusing critics and skeptics of being mentally and morally deranged? [SEP] Yes [SEP] but have you ever tried asking a Christian why, since they preach that Jesus taught the pacifist doctrines of "Resist not evil!" and "Turn the other cheek!", many Christians are among the most violent and militaristic people on the planet? [SEP] What then would happen if everyone learned the central lesson of Gellner's book -- that deception, dishonesty, and manipulation are at the heart not only of the psychoanalytic movement but of nearly all forms of social authority? [SEP] If people simply cease believing in authority, them, like Tinkerbell, authority simply dies [SEP] If the world were free of lies, deception, and manipulation, then the authority of clergymen and governments, of judges, schoolteachers, psychotherapists, professors, and policemen, would all simply disappear [SEP] Garbagemen can still collect garbage, farmers can still farm, and deliverymen can still deliver even if no one "believes' in them [SEP] But if no one believes in clergymen, or psychoanalysts, or Presidents, then there would no longer be clergymen, psychoanalysts, or Presidents [SEP] Like Tinkerbell, they would simply fade away [SEP] And, perhaps, that would be a very good thing indeed

[SEP] Taking David Hume as a prime example, $T$ shows that the scientific, empiricist thought of the Enlightenment abandoned the angel/beast dichotomy [SEP] The Enlightenment theorists naturalized man: the model of man they ended up with, which $T$ dubs the "Bundleman," was a random mixture of self-interested desires and needs which were easily satisfied by a conservatively cautious policy of maximizing pleasure and minimizing pain [SEP] Real human beings, of course, act much more like a mixture of angel and beast than the cautiously and rationally selfish "Bundleman" of the Enlightenment [SEP] Nietzsche was, $T$ claims, the first serious post-Enlightenment thinker to fully realize this fact, and the realization finally drove poor Nietzsche insane [SEP] Freud's genius was to take the Nietzschean insight and domesticate it, thereby turning it into the basis of a very successful, very lucrative pseudo-scientific cult - psychoanalysis [SEP] Freud's task was made easier by certain features of the modern world [SEP] The modern world exhibits deep reverence for applied science, especially medicine [SEP] In modern industrial societies, technology has eradicated most traditional physical threats (starvation, plague, wild animals, etc [SEP] ) [SEP] In our society, the pressing threats perceived by most people lie rather in the increasing complexity of, and importance placed upon, human relationships [SEP] It is just in this area of interpersonal relationships where psychoanalysis offered help [SEP] Most of the book explores the tricks and turns by which psychoanalysis maintained its authority [SEP] Nowadays, now that there is hardly an intelligent person left who is a hard-core believer in the Freudian faith, is this of any more than historical interest? [SEP] Yes [SEP] While Freud may finally be buried, his residue endures -- as "therapy," "couselling," "adjustment," etc [SEP] -- and continues to muddle our thinking process and our ability to make moral evaluations [SEP] As $T$ rhetorically asks, concerning the Holy Grail of "adjustment," "[I]s adaptation, adjustment to any regime, including a tyrannical one, a sign of mental health?" [SEP] Yes [SEP] but have you ever asked a liberal why we must slavishly accede to the results of a democratic election? and psychological needs [SEP] He also focuses in on the specific structural features of modern life that made $T$ an especially successful ideology [SEP] As Gellner sums up in his final chapter, "In a sense, the present book is more interested in our Zeitgeist than in $T$ [SEP] The crucial strategic position occupied by Freudianism in the social and intellectual history of mankind, makes it possible for us to learn a vast amount from it about, on the one hand, the general anatomy of belief systems and, on the other, the special conditions prevalent in our age [SEP] " [SEP] In his first two chapters, Gellner focuses in on what might be called the modern predicament [SEP] Before the rise of natural science and philosophical empiricism, it was easy to explain the mixture of good and evil, the sheer perversity, embodied in human beings [SEP] Humans were, quite literally, halfway between beasts and angels [SEP] The rise of science and modern philosophy invalidated that belief [SEP] Taking David Hume as a prime example, Gellner shows that the scientific, empiricist thought of the Enlightenment abandoned the angel/beast dichotomy [SEP] The Enlightenment theorists naturalized man: the model of man they ended up with, which Gellner dubs the "Bundleman," was a random mixture of self-interested desires and needs which were easily satisfied by a conservatively cautious policy of maximizing pleasure and minimizing pain [SEP] Real human beings, of course, act much more like a mixture of angel and beast than the cautiously and rationally selfish "Bundleman" of the Enlightenment [SEP] Nietzsche was, Gellner claims, the first serious post-Enlightenment thinker to fully realize this fact, and the realization finally drove poor Nietzsche insane [SEP] Freud's genius was to take the Nietzschean insight and domesticate it, thereby turning it into the basis of a very successful, very lucrative pseudo-scientific cult - $T$ [SEP] Freud's task was made easier by certain features of the modern world [SEP] The modern world exhibits deep reverence for applied science, especially medicine [SEP] In modern industrial societies, technology has eradicated most traditional physical threats (starvation, plague, wild animals, etc [SEP] ) [SEP] In our society, the pressing threats perceived by most people lie rather in the increasing complexity of, and importance placed upon, human relationships [SEP] It is just in this area of interpersonal relationships where $T$ offered help [SEP] Most of the book explores the tricks and turns by which $T$ maintained its authority [SEP] [SEP] Yes [SEP] but have you ever asked a liberal why we must slavishly accede to the results of a democratic election? [SEP] I loved this book, so I probably am going to read the next books in this series: [SEP] #2 - Grim Tuesday [SEP] #3 - Drowned Wednesday [SEP] #4 - Sir Thursday [SEP] Coming Soon [SEP] #5 - Lady Friday [SEP] #6 - Superior Saturday [SEP] #7 - Lord Sunday [SEP] Will Arthur save the world from the plague? I did not enjoy this $T$ half as much as i have enjoyed her previous $T$s [SEP] However, that does not mean it is a bad $T$ [SEP] It is actually a very good $T$, one that i expect will appeal to many people [SEP] But it is not what i was expecting, nor what i was looking forward to, and hence i am disappointed [SEP] The basic plot goes thus: Carol Jordan is sent to Berlin on an undercover covert operation to trap an evil traffiker in both drugs and humans [SEP] Her bosses think she will be able to handle it [SEP] During the job she will be almost completely cut off from everybody, and will feel very alone [SEP] Her peril's are increased when the actions of her superiours put her in mortal danger [SEP] Alongside that, psychologists are being murdered on the contient [SEP] Murdered horribly, with no apparent motive [SEP] It is when an ex colleage of profiler Tony Hill's is found slain that he takes it upon himself to investigate the killings [SEP] The emotionally tangled pair must both tackle their own monsters with little help from anyone else and both of them, Carol in particular, will face great personal danger [SEP] It is a very well written $T$, that is undeniable [SEP] However, i cannot say that it is as atmospheric as "A Place of Execution" or as scary and original as "Killing the Shadows", but it is thrilling in a hard-edged way [SEP] But [SEP] McDermid concentrates far too much on Carol Jordan's side of the $T$, and not nearly enough on the serial killer aspect of the plot, which is what she is known for, and what she does best [SEP] As such, the serial killer nit about the psychologists getting killed seems underdeveloped and at times just incidental [SEP] Instead of the tense serial killer novel we expect, we are given a novel mainly about the criminal underworld and undercover policing [SEP] Many people will greatly enjoy this aspect of the $T$ [SEP] And if so, i cannot reccomend it highly enough to you [SEP] But, if you are expecting a nice meaty serial killer novel, reasses your beliefs quickly, because it is not what you're going to get [SEP] Actually a very good novel, just not what i was expecting [SEP] I would have preferred more emphasis on Tony Hill's aspect of the $T$, but we don't always get what we want, and this $T$ certainly displays Carol Jordan's full abilites

many people [SEP] But it is not what i was expecting, nor what i was looking forward to, and hence i am disappointed [SEP] The basic plot goes thus: $T$ is sent to Berlin on an undercover covert operation to trap an evil traffiker in both drugs and humans [SEP] Her bosses think she will be able to handle it [SEP] During the job she will be almost completely cut off from everybody, and will feel very alone [SEP] Her peril's are increased when the actions of her superiours put her in mortal danger [SEP] Alongside that, psychologists are being murdered on the contient [SEP] Murdered horribly, with no apparent motive [SEP] It is when an ex colleage of profiler Tony Hill's is found slain that he takes it upon himself to investigate the killings [SEP] The emotionally tangled pair must both tackle their own monsters with little help from anyone else and both of them, Carol in particular, will face great personal danger [SEP] It is a very well written book, that is undeniable [SEP] However, i cannot say that it is as atmospheric as "A Place of Execution" or as scary and original as "Killing the Shadows", but it is thrilling in a hard-edged way [SEP] But [SEP] McDermid concentrates far too much on $T$'s side of the book, and not nearly enough on the serial killer aspect of the plot, which is what she is known for, and what she does best [SEP] As such, the serial killer nit about the psychologists getting killed seems underdeveloped and at times just incidental [SEP] Instead of the tense serial killer novel we expect, we are given a novel mainly about the criminal underworld and undercover policing [SEP] Many people will greatly enjoy this aspect of the book [SEP] And if so, i cannot reccomend it highly enough to you [SEP] But, if you are expecting a nice meaty serial killer novel, reasses your beliefs quickly, because it is not what you're going to get [SEP] Actually a very good novel, just not what i was expecting [SEP] I would have preferred more emphasis on Tony Hill's aspect of the book, but we don't always get what we want, and this book certainly displays $T$'s full abilites

$T$ has become my new favorite writer, and my discovery started with Mister Monday, the first in the Keys to the Kingdom series [SEP] This opening episode introduces us to Arthur, a displaced but sharp young boy in his first days at a new school [SEP] When a distanced run in gym class brings on a devastating asthma attack, Arthur is supposed to die [SEP] Because he doesn't, he is thrust into a world he never knew existed, with the fate of all worlds in his hands [SEP] Having now read Sabriel, the first in Nix's earlier young adult series, The Abhorsen Trilogy, I can see how far he's come as a writer [SEP] Keys to the Kingdom is superbly paced, and with each new book, we learn a little more about the bigger picture [SEP] The arc of the stories is huge, but strongly anchored in the characters and Nix's attention to details [SEP] Just a note about editions:  I collect books, and while paperbacks are available and cost a little less than the hardcovers, the hardcover editions of these books are very sharp looking on the shelf [SEP] They're colorful and really stand out in a larger collection [SEP] I have to say, I haven't read anything yet by $T$ that I didn't enjoy, but Mister Monday is by far my favorite [SEP] The opening few pages hooked me, and I'm now three books in, anxiously awaiting number four, Sir Thursday, coming out around March!

As a parent, I found the $T$ interesting and thought-provoking, but I did not allow my 7 year old to finish it! Don't assume that advanced reading skills make the 7-10 year old set ready for this one, even though Ms [SEP] Reid-Banks other $T$s are appropriate [SEP] It might be an entertaining point  of discussion with a child 12 or older, but it's too dark for younger ones,  unless you're ready to talk about true evil, adult motivations,  supernatural forces, and fratricide!

Some early young adult novels (it's a fairly new form of literature, you know) age gracefully and seamlessly [SEP] I'm thinking of course of Robert Cormier's "The Chocolate War" and (to a lesser extent), S [SEP] E [SEP] Hinton?s, "The Outsiders" [SEP] Unfortunately, I have a nasty suspicion that these books are the exception rather than the rule [SEP] For every "Forever" there's a "$T$" that contains a great story bogged down by changes in the world [SEP] While Paul Zindel's classic tale of four teenagers and their relationship problems is at times both moving and perfectly toned, mostly the problems presented in it are as dated as they come [SEP] Even a plot synopsis makes this apparent [SEP]  Friends Maggie and Liz aren't exactly close, but they hang out frequently together [SEP] Liz is the more beautiful and popular of the two with Maggie often following behind [SEP] When Liz and her boyfriend Sean decide to hook up Maggie with his friend Dennis, the blind date is as incredibly awkward as they come [SEP] Throughout the book the narrative switches between Maggie and her tentative relationship with Dennis and Liz's problems with Sean [SEP] Sean, like any normal teenager, is as horny as they come and is continually pressuring Liz to have sex [SEP] She'd like to, but she worries that it might end up in pregnancy [SEP] Unsurprisingly, that is exactly what happens and soon the big question in the book is whether or not Sean will do the honorable thing and marry Liz (!!) or if Liz will seek out an illegal abortion on her own [SEP]  It's this last plotline that struck me as dated [SEP] The book was originally written in 1969, a full three years before Roe V [SEP] Wade and in many ways this abortion issue (while it still looms large) isn't the same [SEP] Sure, many girls will sweat over what to do with an unplanned pregnancy, but crossing the border to a state where abortion is legal is probably a more up-to-date literary solution than getting a back alley job [SEP] Then there's the debate about whether a girl should marry the guy who gets her pregnant, regardless of how old they are or what their future plans are [SEP] Maybe there are pockets of the country where this really is the only honorable solution to such a problem, but it's really not how the majority of teens would handle it today [SEP] The book is additionally riddled with small cultural time capsules as well [SEP] Talk about how Orientals kill themselves for honor, going to the movie theater to watch a documentary on pygmies, and the complete and total lack of any mention of STDs all combine to make this book an interesting window into the past [SEP] To some degree it does still speak to teens today [SEP] I was especially amused by the Sex Ed [SEP] teacher's advice on how to stop a guy from going all the way, (suggest going out for a hamburger) [SEP] The characters were interesting as well [SEP] Liz, unfortunately, isn't a character you're going to identify with intrinsically [SEP] Yes, it's sad that she doesn't get along with her parents [SEP] But she's such a self-absorbed person, constantly ridiculing her best friend and at the same time dragging Maggie into horrid and dangerous situations, that by the end you feel zippo pity for her [SEP] In fact, you're supposed to end this story hating and pitying Sean who got her pregnant in the first place [SEP] Curse those lustful young men that refuse to marry their knocked up girlfriends! Curse them! This book probably read very well in the 1970s and I could even see it having some interesting points in the 1980s [SEP] But by the 1990s with the advent of AIDS better known and the options available to teens widening, books like this one began to read more as cautionary tales than as contemporary novels [SEP] I've no doubt that "$T$" was riveting and shocking when it first came out [SEP] Unfortunately, that's certainly no longer the case [SEP] I recommend it as a glimpse into the America that once was [SEP] If you'd like to know more about the history of the Young Adult novel, this is a good book to pick up [SEP] Just don't expect it to have too many insights to offer today [SEP] I'm afraid it's no longer that meaningful

Darling, My Hamburger" that contains a great story bogged down by changes in the world [SEP] While Paul Zindel's $T$ of four teenagers and their relationship problems is at times both moving and perfectly toned, mostly the problems presented in it are as dated as they come [SEP] Even a plot synopsis makes this apparent [SEP]  Friends Maggie and Liz aren't exactly close, but they hang out frequently together [SEP] Liz is the more beautiful and popular of the two with Maggie often following behind [SEP] When Liz and her boyfriend Sean decide to hook up Maggie with his friend Dennis, the blind date is as incredibly awkward as they come [SEP] Throughout the book the narrative switches between Maggie and her tentative relationship with Dennis and Liz's problems with Sean [SEP] Sean, like any normal teenager, is as horny as they come and is continually pressuring Liz to have sex [SEP] She'd like to, but she worries that it might end up in pregnancy [SEP] Unsurprisingly, that is exactly what happens and soon the big question in the book is whether or not Sean will do the honorable thing and marry Liz (!!) or if Liz will seek out an illegal abortion on her own [SEP]  It's this last plotline that struck me as dated [SEP] The book was originally written in 1969, a full three years before Roe V [SEP] Wade and in many ways this abortion issue (while it still looms large) isn't the same [SEP] Sure, many girls will sweat over what to do with an unplanned pregnancy, but crossing the border to a state where abortion is legal is probably a more up-to-date literary solution than getting a back alley job [SEP] Then there's the debate about whether a girl should marry the guy who gets her pregnant, regardless of how old they are or what their future plans are [SEP] Maybe there are pockets of the country where this really is the only honorable solution to such a problem, but it's really not how the majority of teens would handle it today [SEP] The book is additionally riddled with small cultural time capsules as well [SEP] Talk about how Orientals kill themselves for honor, going to the movie theater to watch a documentary on pygmies, and the complete and total lack of any mention of STDs all combine to make this book an interesting window into the past [SEP] To some degree it does still speak to teens today [SEP] I was especially amused by the Sex Ed [SEP] teacher's advice on how to stop a guy from going all the way, (suggest going out for a hamburger) [SEP] The characters were interesting as well [SEP] Liz, unfortunately, isn't a character you're going to identify with intrinsically [SEP] Yes, it's sad that she doesn't get along with her parents [SEP] But she's such a self-absorbed person, constantly ridiculing her best friend and at the same time dragging Maggie into horrid and dangerous situations, that by the end you feel zippo pity for her [SEP] In fact, you're supposed to end this story hating and pitying Sean who got her pregnant in the first place [SEP] Curse those lustful young men that refuse to marry their knocked up girlfriends! Curse them! This book probably read very well in the 1970s and I could even see it having some interesting points in the 1980s [SEP] But by the 1990s with the advent of AIDS better known and the options available to teens widening, books like this one began to read more as cautionary tales than as contemporary novels [SEP] I've no doubt that "My Darling, My Hamburger" was riveting and shocking when it first came out [SEP] Unfortunately, that's certainly no longer the case [SEP] I recommend it as a glimpse into the America that once was [SEP] If you'd like to know more about the history of the Young Adult novel, this is a good book to pick up [SEP] Just don't expect it to have too many insights to offer today [SEP] I'm afraid it's no longer that meaningful

and perfectly toned, mostly the problems presented in it are as dated as they come [SEP] Even a plot synopsis makes this apparent [SEP]  Friends Maggie and Liz aren't exactly close, but they hang out frequently together [SEP] Liz is the more beautiful and popular of the two with Maggie often following behind [SEP] When Liz and her boyfriend $T$ decide to hook up Maggie with his friend Dennis, the blind date is as incredibly awkward as they come [SEP] Throughout the book the narrative switches between Maggie and her tentative relationship with Dennis and Liz's problems with $T$ [SEP] $T$, like any normal teenager, is as horny as they come and is continually pressuring Liz to have sex [SEP] She'd like to, but she worries that it might end up in pregnancy [SEP] Unsurprisingly, that is exactly what happens and soon the big question in the book is whether or not $T$ will do the honorable thing and marry Liz (!!) or if Liz will seek out an illegal abortion on her own [SEP]  It's this last plotline that struck me as dated [SEP] The book was originally written in 1969, a full three years before Roe V [SEP] Wade and in many ways this abortion issue (while it still looms large) isn't the same [SEP] Sure, many girls will sweat over what to do with an unplanned pregnancy, but crossing the border to a state where abortion is legal is probably a more up-to-date literary solution than getting a back alley job [SEP] Then there's the debate about whether a girl should marry the guy who gets her pregnant, regardless of how old they are or what their future plans are [SEP] Maybe there are pockets of the country where this really is the only honorable solution to such a problem, but it's really not how the majority of teens would handle it today [SEP] The book is additionally riddled with small cultural time capsules as well [SEP] Talk about how Orientals kill themselves for honor, going to the movie theater to watch a documentary on pygmies, and the complete and total lack of any mention of STDs all combine to make this book an interesting window into the past [SEP] To some degree it does still speak to teens today [SEP] I was especially amused by the Sex Ed [SEP] teacher's advice on how to stop a guy from going all the way, (suggest going out for a hamburger) [SEP] The characters were interesting as well [SEP] Liz, unfortunately, isn't a character you're going to identify with intrinsically [SEP] Yes, it's sad that she doesn't get along with her parents [SEP] But she's such a self-absorbed person, constantly ridiculing her best friend and at the same time dragging Maggie into horrid and dangerous situations, that by the end you feel zippo pity for her [SEP] In fact, you're supposed to end this story hating and pitying $T$ who got her pregnant in the first place [SEP] Curse those lustful young men that refuse to marry their knocked up girlfriends! Curse them! This book probably read very well in the 1970s and I could even see it having some interesting points in the 1980s [SEP] But by the 1990s with the advent of AIDS better known and the options available to teens widening, books like this one began to read more as cautionary tales than as contemporary novels [SEP] I've no doubt that "My Darling, My Hamburger" was riveting and shocking when it first came out [SEP] Unfortunately, that's certainly no longer the case [SEP] I recommend it as a glimpse into the America that once was [SEP] If you'd like to know more about the history of the Young Adult novel, this is a good book to pick up [SEP] Just don't expect it to have too many insights to offer today [SEP] I'm afraid it's no longer that meaningful

I don't think I understood the whole thing, but it's not all my fault [SEP] Deliberately author $T$ splits up his story between the first person narration of ex-cop/coffee table book captionist Jack Whelan, with a variety of third person accounts that are purposely confusing and disparate, so that you need a second reading to be able to piece it all together properly [SEP] I kept skimming and skimming, thinking with my fingers crossed that "this will all make sense later, I'm sure," but eventually I got at least a glimmer of a storyline involving a young nine year old girl who at first seems like she's been kidnapped by an evil, foul smelling man, but within a few pages we find out that this "abduction" is not really what it seems and the the 9 year old, cute little Madison, exhibits the cold, maniacal soullessness of an adult, and an especially demented one at that [SEP] But why?  Why?  Why?  She's like Patty McCormack in THE BAD SEED, but why?  Author Marshall has a new theory about why some kids hit the ground running, while others just go to the devil [SEP] He grabs your lapels and shakes this theory into you until you reach a point where you just want to slap his hands away, he's so insistent [SEP] On the home front, Jack is married to a woman who, just like in all the best postwar noir stories, isn't what she seems [SEP] This part of the story would seem more original if it hadn't been done just last month in the techno thriller HOOKED [SEP] Searching for the truth about his wife, Jack turns more and more to an old high school friend, Gary Fisher, once an idolized athletic hero in school, later a top lawyer, but obviously a man with a burning mission [SEP] As Jack grows suspicious of Amy, he grows closer and closer to Gary (who in the conventional thriller would have been a woman I think), and their eventual friendship and bonding has a distinct homoerotic charge to it as they both learn that women (and little girls) can't be trusted [SEP] Marshall makes you read through to the end but you'll be scratching your head over many of his plot choices, and I can't make up my mind whether the story is actually crazy stupid, or maybe too smart for a moron like myself

I don't think I understood the whole thing, but it's not all my fault [SEP] Deliberately author Michael Marshall splits up his story between the first person narration of ex-cop/coffee table book captionist Jack Whelan, with a variety of third person accounts that are purposely confusing and disparate, so that you need a second reading to be able to piece it all together properly [SEP] I kept skimming and skimming, thinking with my fingers crossed that "this will all make sense later, I'm sure," but eventually I got at least a glimmer of a storyline involving a young nine year old girl who at first seems like she's been kidnapped by an evil, foul smelling man, but within a few pages we find out that this "abduction" is not really what it seems and the the 9 year old, cute little Madison, exhibits the cold, maniacal soullessness of an adult, and an especially demented one at that [SEP] But why? I stumbled upon this book in a Scholastic (or some such) catalog from my mother who is a middle school teacher [SEP] She's been buying me whatever kids' books I've wanted from the catalogs and it's been rather hit and miss [SEP] In any case, I wasn't expecting much but I was overwhelmed by the complexity yet clearness of $T$'s writing [SEP] I noticed there were no reviews on the cover and was surprised, continually, that I'd not heard of him before [SEP] This is a new favorite!  By the way, I'm 30

Like many career-minded $T$ my age, I have no immediate plans to marry, and I would certainly read thuis book a second time if I were ever going to [SEP] We can yap all we want about the importance of committment and love in modern day marriage, but the fact remains that Marriage, as an institution, can be a degrading, wasteful, and downright evil thing [SEP] I think a lot of women get married nowadays because it is quite simply the thing to do [SEP] A book like this would enable them to make a rational decision in that regard!!

Former LAPD cop turned author $T$ and his wife advertising executive Amy left Southern California to live in the Seattle suburbs [SEP] One seemingly uneventful day high school sports friend Gary Fisher calls from Chicago to ask Jack to do him a favor [SEP] The lawyer says he tracked Jack from his book and would like Jack to investigate the brutal murders of thirty-seven year old Gina Anderson and her son Joshua in their Seattle home; the house was trashed and the husband a lecturer at the nearby community college vanished [SEP] Jack agrees to take the case, but when he calls his wife who is in Seattle on business, the hotel desk clerk says she has not checked in and she fails to answer her cell phone [SEP] Concerned he travels to Seattle to find Amy has vanished [SEP] In Portland, a nine years old girl also disappears, but is found a few miles away [SEP] She shares visions with Jack, who digs deeper into a cesspool in search of his wife [SEP] Soon all three scenarios will connect at the heart of Jack's soul [SEP] THE INTRUDERS affirm Michael Marshall's winning of the Philip K [SEP] Dick [SEP] Award (see THE STRAW MEN) as this action-packed thriller filled with twists will keep readers on the edge throughout [SEP] Jack is a wonderful beleaguered hero who starts off by quickly realizing he don't know jack even about himself and as he investigates realizes each new clue proves he knows even less than he thought [SEP] The audience needs to set aside plenty of time as 392 pages is a one sitting suspense read [SEP] Harriet Klausner

Of all her family, only Grandmother understands, or even has time for, $T$'s story of catching a magical golden leaf, the kind that makes sand pies--and dreams--real, because she had caught one too when she was young

ok maybe not soo much, but a couple of pages and [SEP] I was hooked!!$T$ is a awesome writer and though the book is a little babyish - its definetly worth a read!I thought the whole minute - hand - is - a - key part was a real good idea plus the names are so fun!The only thing I didn't like was that Arthur doesen't take his rightful place as "Monday" [SEP] He chose to go home which, no offense to anyone, is a little wimpy!On Athur Phenaligon's first day at his new school, things don't go quite as he had expected [SEP] His gym teacher forces him to run a cross country race even though he explains that he had just recovered from a serious bout of Asthama [SEP] Arthur runs the race and (Big Surprise) suffers an asthama attack [SEP] He was about to die when he was handed a minute shaped key from Mister Monday [SEP] Er hello? where did THAT come in?Assuming it to be a hallucination Arthur tries to forget about it as he is rushed into the hospital [SEP] When he recovers, the "key" and " A Compleat Atlas of The House" are still there [SEP] Thats when Arthur awakens to the reality of his dream [SEP] Along with the key comes these [SEP] creatures who bring a plague scientist simply can't find a cure for [SEP] Arthur is desperate and so ventures into "The House" where the answers seems to lie [SEP] Did I mention he was the only one who could see it?Within the house Arthur meets the "Piper's Children" (You heard me!)Actually one of them in particular - Suzy Turquoise Blue and along with her they face many [SEP] um "perils" as well as the complications of the house and it's creator, The ArchitectAnyway read this book, its way cool

I first stumbled across $T$ in one of those gift shops you find in bigger hotels [SEP] I wandered over to the paperback "section" --- it was a wall mounting, containing slots for nine titles --- and I noticed the name "$T$" on a copy of THE STRAW MEN [SEP] I went to grade school with a $T$, so I picked up the book to see if perhaps it was the same gentleman [SEP] They turned out to be different people altogether [SEP] But I was so intrigued by the premise of the novel that I bought it, read it and quickly sought out the remainder of the author's bibliography [SEP] THE INTRUDERS is Marshall's latest work, combining his trademark elements of unpredictability, craftsmanship and sterling characterization to provide an addicting, thrilling read that never disappoints [SEP] If you're paranoid at all, you're going to get your instincts jumpstarted within a few pages of reading THE INTRUDERS [SEP] The story deals primarily with Jack Whalen, a man who is unsettled by the feeling that his world is slowly, almost imperceptibly, changing [SEP] Whalen is an ex-LAPD patrolman who retired from the force, wrote a book of some nominal success and now lives with his wife Amy --- a successful marketing executive --- in a small rural community a few hours removed from Seattle [SEP] Their world seems to be financially and emotionally secure [SEP] But, as Marshall slowly reveals, there are tiny cracks around the foundation of the Whalen family --- not necessarily fissures or yawning chasms, but cracks nonetheless [SEP] When Amy turns up missing during what would otherwise be a routine business trip to Seattle, Jack immediately begins to investigate, only to discover that her disappearance is more a misunderstanding than anything else [SEP] That's not the end of it, however [SEP] Jack notices that his wife is doing little things --- acquiring new habits, listening to different music --- that she has never done before [SEP] Taken together, they portend the arrival of something far beyond anything that Jack can imagine [SEP] In the meantime, events occurring that appear far removed from Jack's world will jeopardize his very existence [SEP] A mysterious stranger breaks into a house, brutally murders a woman and her son, and sets the house on fire [SEP] A young girl, walking alone on a beach, is approached by a polite man and shortly thereafter leaves without explanation, even as her demeanor begins to change [SEP] And Amy? She just gets more and more bizarre [SEP] As you're reading, you will probably find yourself wondering just how Marshall is going to tie up such apparently disparate elements into a cohesive story, and to what ultimate end [SEP] What Marshall does, however, is not only create a chilling tale that will keep you awake at night, but he also provides a possible answer to a question that has puzzled individuals for hundreds of years: What, precisely, makes us what, and who, we are? [SEP] Those familiar with Marshall's body of work wish that he would write more frequently [SEP] But when he publishes a novel of such quality as THE INTRUDERS, one remembers that any book of his is worth the wait, no matter how long it may be [SEP] --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaub

I first stumbled across Michael Marshall in one of those gift shops you find in bigger hotels [SEP] I wandered over to the paperback "section" --- it was a wall mounting, containing slots for nine titles --- and I noticed the name "Michael Marshall" on a copy of THE STRAW MEN [SEP] I went to grade school with a Michael Marshall, so I picked up the book to see if perhaps it was the same gentleman [SEP] They turned out to be different people altogether [SEP] But I was so intrigued by the premise of the novel that I bought it, read it and quickly sought out the remainder of the author's bibliography [SEP] $T$ is Marshall's latest work, combining his trademark elements of unpredictability, craftsmanship and sterling characterization to provide an addicting, thrilling read that never disappoints [SEP] If you're paranoid at all, you're going to get your instincts jumpstarted within a few pages of reading $T$ [SEP] The story deals primarily with Jack Whalen, a man who is unsettled by the feeling that his world is slowly, almost imperceptibly, changing [SEP] Whalen is an ex-LAPD patrolman who retired from the force, wrote a book of some nominal success and now lives with his wife Amy --- a successful marketing executive --- in a small rural community a few hours removed from Seattle [SEP] Their world seems to be financially and emotionally secure [SEP] But, as Marshall slowly reveals, there are tiny cracks around the foundation of the Whalen family --- not necessarily fissures or yawning chasms, but cracks nonetheless [SEP] When Amy turns up missing during what would otherwise be a routine business trip to Seattle, Jack immediately begins to investigate, only to discover that her disappearance is more a misunderstanding than anything else [SEP] That's not the end of it, however [SEP] Jack notices that his wife is doing little things --- acquiring new habits, listening to different music --- that she has never done before [SEP] Taken together, they portend the arrival of something far beyond anything that Jack can imagine [SEP] In the meantime, events occurring that appear far removed from Jack's world will jeopardize his very existence [SEP] A mysterious stranger breaks into a house, brutally murders a woman and her son, and sets the house on fire [SEP] A young girl, walking alone on a beach, is approached by a polite man and shortly thereafter leaves without explanation, even as her demeanor begins to change [SEP] And Amy? She just gets more and more bizarre [SEP] As you're reading, you will probably find yourself wondering just how Marshall is going to tie up such apparently disparate elements into a cohesive story, and to what ultimate end [SEP] What Marshall does, however, is not only create a chilling tale that will keep you awake at night, but he also provides a possible answer to a question that has puzzled individuals for hundreds of years: What, precisely, makes us what, and who, we are? [SEP] Those familiar with Marshall's body of work wish that he would write more frequently [SEP] But when he publishes a novel of such quality as $T$, one remembers that any book of his is worth the wait, no matter how long it may be [SEP] --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaub

what would otherwise be a routine business trip to Seattle, Jack immediately begins to investigate, only to discover that her disappearance is more a misunderstanding than anything else [SEP] That's not the end of it, however [SEP] Jack notices that his wife is doing little things --- acquiring new habits, listening to different music --- that she has never done before [SEP] Taken together, they portend the arrival of something far beyond anything that Jack can imagine [SEP] In the meantime, events occurring that appear far removed from Jack's world will jeopardize his very existence [SEP] A She just gets more and more bizarre [SEP] As you're reading, you will probably find yourself wondering just how Marshall is going to tie up such apparently disparate elements into a cohesive story, and to what ultimate end [SEP] What Marshall does, however, is not only create a chilling tale that will keep you awake at night, but he also provides a possible answer to a question that has puzzled individuals for hundreds of years: What, precisely, makes us what, and who, we are? I first stumbled across Michael Marshall in one of those gift shops you find in bigger hotels [SEP] I wandered over to the paperback "section" --- it was a wall mounting, containing slots for nine titles --- and I noticed the name "Michael Marshall" on a copy of THE STRAW MEN [SEP] I went to grade school with a Michael Marshall, so I picked up the book to see if perhaps it was the same gentleman [SEP] They turned out to be different people altogether [SEP] But I was so intrigued by the premise of the novel that I bought it, read it and quickly sought out the remainder of the author's bibliography [SEP] THE INTRUDERS is Marshall's latest work, combining his trademark elements of unpredictability, craftsmanship and sterling characterization to provide an addicting, thrilling read that never disappoints [SEP] If you're paranoid at all, you're going to get your instincts jumpstarted within a few pages of reading THE INTRUDERS [SEP] The story deals primarily with Jack Whalen, a man who is unsettled by the feeling that his world is slowly, almost imperceptibly, changing [SEP] Whalen is an ex-LAPD patrolman who retired from the force, wrote a book of some nominal success and now lives with his wife $T$ --- a successful marketing executive --- in a small rural community a few hours removed from Seattle [SEP] Their world seems to be financially and emotionally secure [SEP] But, as Marshall slowly reveals, there are tiny cracks around the foundation of the Whalen family --- not necessarily fissures or yawning chasms, but cracks nonetheless [SEP] When $T$ turns up missing during what would otherwise be a routine business trip to Seattle, Jack immediately begins to investigate, only to discover that her disappearance is more a misunderstanding than anything else [SEP] That's not the end of it, however [SEP] Jack notices that his wife is doing little things --- acquiring new habits, listening to different music --- that she has never done before [SEP] Taken together, they portend the arrival of something far beyond anything that Jack can imagine [SEP] In the meantime, events occurring that appear far removed from Jack's world will jeopardize his very existence [SEP] A mysterious stranger breaks into a house, brutally murders a woman and her son, and sets the house on fire [SEP] A young girl, walking alone on a beach, is approached by a polite man and shortly thereafter leaves without explanation, even as her demeanor begins to change [SEP] And $T$? She just gets more and more bizarre [SEP] As you're reading, you will probably find yourself wondering just how Marshall is going to tie up such apparently disparate elements into a cohesive story, and to what ultimate end [SEP] What Marshall does, however, is not only create a chilling tale that will keep you awake at night, but he also provides a possible answer to a question that has puzzled individuals for hundreds of years: What, precisely, makes us what, and who, we are? [SEP] Those familiar with Marshall's body of work wish that he would write more frequently [SEP] But when he publishes a novel of such quality as THE INTRUDERS, one remembers that any book of his is worth the wait, no matter how long it may be [SEP] --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaub

$T$ is an excellent new series by Garth Nix - a series I cannot wait for the sequel too! To get the concept of the book, you kind of have to read it, really [SEP] When Arthur is suffering from a asthma attack, two men appear to him, and one gives him a key shaped like the minute hand of an old clock [SEP] After that day, he starts seeing a large house [SEP] He is followed by creatures called Fetchers [SEP] Also, a book appears to him that is very useful [SEP] When a disease breaks out, he finds that it is spread by the Fetchers [SEP] Arthur sets off into the house to find a way to save his world

If you are looking for a $T$, I recommend that you read the series of books The Keys to the Kingdom by Garth Nix [SEP] This mysterious novel is about a boy called Arthur Penhaligon who is not supposed to be a hero; he is in fact, supposed to die an early death [SEP] But his life is saved by a minute hand shaped key [SEP] Arthur is safe [SEP] but his world is in danger [SEP] Along with the key comes a plague brought by creatures from another realm [SEP] A villain, his messenger with blood stained wings, and an army of dog faced creatures will do anything to get the key back, even if it means destroying Arthur and everything that surrounds him [SEP] Desperate to save his world, Arthur ventures into a mysterious house that only he can see [SEP] In this house, Arthur will have to unravel the key's secrets and discover his true fate

The cover of this book is striking, and helped convince me to buy it [SEP] It asks what it means to be a wife today, when wives are both made fun of in pop culture and also sometimes held up as the ideal [SEP] As a newlywed myself, I wanted an answer to that question [SEP] $T$ does a great job of weaving together pop culture and history, and she's a fun writer [SEP] She points out interesting trends, such as the fact that many high-powered women, such as Oprah, choose not to marry today [SEP] Sometimes I found myself rereading sentences because they were a bit esoteric, but overall the book is extremely accessible and thought-provoking

$T$ (and that just has to be a reference to the Arthurian legend) is just an average kid with bad asthma, until he has an attack that nearly kills him and suddenly finds himself a big player in a world that exists outside reality as he knows it [SEP] Arthur's Earth is one set in the future to begin with, which is a bit hard to follow through his reflections on previous events, but it gets even more confusing when he receives on of the Keys and finds the House that is a gateway to another world/time/reality [SEP] Time moves differently there and the laws of nature/physics mean nothing [SEP] In fact, Nothing pays a large role in the story, the substance out of which many things, good and bad can be created [SEP] The Architect (the creator of everything) left a long time ago, but she left instructions as to how things were to be run, a sentient Will [SEP] But the trustees defied it and set out to do things their own way [SEP] So now it's up to Arthur to set things to right [SEP] The Will is going to find a way, and that way is Arthur [SEP] The descriptions of Arthur's travels through the House are both interesting and highly confusing at times [SEP] I had to reread a few parts more than once to figure out what was going on [SEP] You do, eventually, get used to it, but it takes a long while and I felt a bit lost for half of the book [SEP] The Stairway was one of the better touches, I thought, those glimpses into the past [SEP] Suzy is an excellent character, a good partner/guide for Arthur and the best friend he could have in this world [SEP] I, like other reviewers, though, wish that a lot more had been done with Leaf and her brother Ed [SEP] The way they were introduced led me to believe that they'd play a much bigger role, as would Arthur's world, neither of which happened [SEP] The character development is very slim, too [SEP] Much more attention is paid to plot development, which, while nice, is only one half a needed whole [SEP] I'm hoping that the second book will take the time to flesh the characters out a bit

player in a world that exists outside reality as he knows it [SEP] Arthur's Earth is one set in the future to begin with, which is a bit hard to follow through his reflections on previous events, but it gets even more confusing when he receives on of the Keys and finds the House that is a gateway to another world/time/reality [SEP] Time moves differently there and the laws of nature/physics mean nothing [SEP] In fact, Nothing pays a large role in the story, the substance out of which many things, good and bad can be created [SEP] The Architect (the creator of everything) left a long time ago, but she left instructions as to how things were to be run, a sentient Will [SEP] But the trustees defied it and set out to do things their own way [SEP] So now it's up to Arthur to set things to right [SEP] The Will is going to find a way, and that way is Arthur [SEP] The descriptions of Arthur's travels through the House are both interesting and highly confusing at times [SEP] I had to reread a few parts more than once to figure out what was going on [SEP] You do, eventually, get used to it, but it takes a long while and I felt a bit lost for half of the book [SEP] The Stairway was one of the better touches, I thought, those glimpses into the past [SEP] Suzy is an excellent character, a good partner/guide for Arthur and the best friend he could have in this world [SEP] I, like other reviewers, though, wish that a lot more had been done with Leaf and her brother Ed [SEP] The way they were introduced led me to believe that they'd play a much bigger role, as would Arthur's world, that the second book will take the time to flesh the characters out a bit

Arthur Penhaligon (and that just has to be a reference to the Arthurian legend) is just an average kid with bad asthma, until he has an attack that nearly kills him and suddenly finds himself a big player in a world that exists outside reality as he knows it [SEP] Arthur's Earth is one set in the future to begin with, which is a bit hard to follow through his reflections on previous events, but it gets even more confusing when he receives on of the Keys and finds the House that is a gateway to another world/time/reality [SEP] Time moves differently there and the laws of nature/physics mean nothing [SEP] In fact, Nothing pays a large role in the story, the substance out of which many things, good and bad can be created [SEP] The Architect (the creator of everything) left a long time ago, but she left instructions as to how things were to be run, a sentient Will [SEP] But the trustees defied it and set out to do things their own way [SEP] So now it's up to Arthur to set things to right [SEP] The Will is going to find a way, and that way is Arthur [SEP] The descriptions of Arthur's travels through the House are both interesting and highly confusing at times [SEP] I had to reread a few parts more than once to figure out what was going on [SEP] You do, eventually, get used to it, but it takes a long while and I felt a bit lost for half of the book [SEP] The Stairway was one of the better touches, I thought, those glimpses into the past [SEP] Suzy is an excellent character, a good partner/guide for Arthur and the best friend he could have in this world [SEP] I, like other reviewers, though, wish that a lot more had been done with Leaf and her brother Ed [SEP] The way they were introduced led me to believe that they'd play a much bigger role, as would Arthur's world, neither of which happened [SEP] The character development is very slim, too [SEP] Much more attention is paid to $T$, which, while nice, is only one half a needed whole [SEP] I'm hoping that the second book will take the time to flesh the characters out a bit

I really enjoyed this $T$ [SEP] The $T$ explores the role of the wife in society from a historical perspective and does a very good job illustrating how tht role has changed over time [SEP] I think I found the $T$ interesting because I was able to compare my views on wifedom and marriage to the views my mom has [SEP] I have to say that being a 30 year old woman in 2005 that my perspective on my life as it relates to marriage is dramatically different than the perspective my mother had when she married my father [SEP] Back in the 1960's, there weren't the career options that exist today [SEP] There were very clearly defined roles and expectations [SEP] I think that after having read this $T$ I can still see how society is relucutant to rid itself of those same roles - they are merely masked or contorted so that they appear different [SEP] Women today are told they "can have it all" and back then it was "this is all you get" [SEP] Well, women really can't have it all and that is presenting a host of new issues for them to deal with [SEP] The reference material in this $T$ is very good and numerous examples were selected to support each theory presented [SEP] A very interesting read for both married and unmarried individuals [SEP] I would also recommend this $T$ as a $T$ club selection because I can definitely see women talking about this in depth - from the heart

I guess one could say there  must be a sort of balance between good and evil [SEP] It is often said that one CANNOT exist without the other [SEP] At first I was amused an entertained by $T$ the novel by Lynne Reid Banks, but as it progressed and became exceedingly darker, I read the jacket to  find that this book was recommended for ages 9-12 [SEP] I don't think so [SEP] Especially in this day and age [SEP] Doing bad thing (especially super bad things) is never a good idea [SEP] However, there were a couple of things that bothered me about the story [SEP] I expected there to be some explanation as to the WHY the twins existed, something a little more magical or ethereal [SEP] The clever ruse of incorporating the two entities into one was interesting and the only way the author could justify Diabola's so called death, but I felt there should have been a little more explanation as where they came from [SEP] Also I felt there was a hint at Mrs [SEP] Cuthburtson-Joneses (the mother) having some sort of unrealized power that never was explored or expanded [SEP] I enjoyed the story, but I still don't think its right for pre-teens

On the face of it, $T$ is very poor material for a hero [SEP] He is so severely asthmatic that an attack brought on by a compulsory cross-country run at his new school is about to end his life [SEP] Someone on the point of death is exactly what the sinister stranger Mister Monday wants, and he gives Arthur a key shaped like the minute hand of a clock [SEP] But it doesn't work as Mister Monday intended, for with the key in his hand Arthur can breathe as though he has never had asthma [SEP] However, along with the key comes a plague brought by bizarre creatures from another realm--dog-faced men in bowler hats called Fetchers [SEP] These, along with Mr Monday and his avenging messengers with blood-stained wings, will stop at nothing to get back the key, even if it means destroying Arthur and everything around him [SEP] In desperation, Arthur ventures into a mysterious house--a house only he can see [SEP] This is where Arthur must unravel the secrets of the key and discover his true fate [SEP] I found this book (especially the Prologue) more bizarre than either Sabriel or Lirael, but every bit as engrossing [SEP] I have to marvel at an author who publishes the first book in a long and complex series without having first written all the others [SEP] I wouldn't like it myself because if a brilliant deviation from the outlined plot occurred to me for a later book, but it needed a rewrite of the first book, this couldn't be done [SEP] Garth Nix has a hard act to follow in this first, highly imaginative book of The Keys to the Kingdom [SEP] And he has to do it six times! [SEP] Incidentally, I read the following in a review by a young reader here on amazon [SEP] com and had to smile [SEP] "Written slightly below the level of the Harry Potter books this series should still capture the attention and imagination of young readers attracted to these types of stories [SEP] I found it to be a fun and enchanting read, maybe a little tame, but then I'm somewhat older than the target audience [SEP] " [SEP] How he could have found Arthur's ordeals "tame" I have no idea! And the first Harry Potter book was very firmly a middle-grade novel, despite its length [SEP] Amazon [SEP] com rates its readership the same as for Mister Monday--ages 9-12, which would be about right [SEP] I call that the upper end of the middle-grade readership [SEP] Too many books suitable for this age group are classed as "young adult"--possibly because the readership of YA books is more likely to be 15 and under than genuine young adults, and many young readers like to feel they are reading above their age level, so authors and publishers pander to this [SEP] I do know that at age 15 I wouldn't have "been seen dead" reading a children's book because, even though 15-year-olds of my generation were considerably less sophisticated than today's 15-year-olds, I considered myself "too old--nearly grown up" [SEP] Make what you like of that [SEP] :-)

And the first Harry Potter book was very firmly a middle-grade novel, despite its length [SEP] Amazon [SEP] com rates its readership the same as for Mister Monday--ages 9-12, which would be about right [SEP] I call that the upper end of the middle-grade readership [SEP] Too many books suitable for this age group are classed as "young adult"--possibly because the readership of YA books is more likely to be 15 and under than genuine young adults, and many young readers like to feel they are reading above their age level, so authors and publishers pander to this [SEP] I do know that at age 15 I wouldn't have "been seen dead" reading a children's book because, even though 15-year-olds of my generation were considerably less sophisticated than today's 15-year-olds, I considered myself "too old--nearly grown up" [SEP] Make what you like of that [SEP] :-)
