On the face of it, Arthur Penhaligon is very poor material for a hero [SEP] He is so severely asthmatic that an attack brought on by a compulsory cross-country run at his new school is about to end his life [SEP] Someone on the point of death is exactly what the sinister stranger $T$ wants, and he gives Arthur a key shaped like the minute hand of a clock [SEP] But it doesn't work as $T$ intended, for with the key in his hand Arthur can breathe as though he has never had asthma [SEP] However, along with the key comes a plague brought by bizarre creatures from another realm--dog-faced men in bowler hats called Fetchers [SEP] These, along with Mr Monday and his avenging messengers with blood-stained wings, will stop at nothing to get back the key, even if it means destroying Arthur and everything around him [SEP] In desperation, Arthur ventures into a mysterious house--a house only he can see [SEP] This is where Arthur must unravel the secrets of the key and discover his true fate [SEP] I found this book (especially the Prologue) more bizarre than either Sabriel or Lirael, but every bit as engrossing [SEP] I have to marvel at an author who publishes the first book in a long and complex series without having first written all the others [SEP] I wouldn't like it myself because if a brilliant deviation from the outlined plot occurred to me for a later book, but it needed a rewrite of the first book, this couldn't be done [SEP] Garth Nix has a hard act to follow in this first, highly imaginative book of The Keys to the Kingdom [SEP] And he has to do it six times! This book explores the manner in which European - well British anyway - people became familiar with $T$ from the 1700s on [SEP] It is mostly about the discoverers, but also reveals a lot about what they discovered [SEP] And the mysteries that remain [SEP] The ancient Harappan civilisation - so developed and yet so static - the Hindu culture and the Buddha who grew within it (but where have the $T$n Buddhist gone today - how were they driven away or why did the philosophy become unfashionable), the Jains - a sect of the Buddhists? And then there are the aboriginal peoples of $T$, the Moslem invasions, and, of course, the British [SEP] I have had the good fortune to visit $T$ on several trips - visiting the Taj Mahal, the caves at Elephanta, and Mahabalipuram [SEP] But the most spectacular site for me is Khajuraho [SEP] All these places are mentioned by Mr Keay (and, of course, many I have not visited) and I found it interesting to read about how each has a context in $T$n history and helps us to understand better this continent of enormous population, of refined culture, and of such diverse mixtures of race [SEP] But the most amazing thing to me is the realisation that so many of these sites were abandoned ruins that had to be found, explored, restored, conserved [SEP] What rich pickings there were for those British colonials who took the continent to heart, and were not repulsed by its alienness [SEP] Khajuraho is a case in point, where the erotic nature of much of the adorned temples was a real shock to early explorers [SEP] And yet Mr Keay has some great words for it:"No pin-up ever approached the provocative postures, the smouldering looks and the langourous gestures of the Khajuraho nymphs [SEP] Serene rather than saucy, intent rather than ecstatic, they go gracefully about their feminine business, adjusting the hair, applying eye shadow, removing a splinter, approaching their lovers; then the kiss, the caress, the passionate love-making of first aquaintance, and the erotic experiments of a mature affection [SEP] Here there is love and beauty, passion and joy, instruction even and inspiration; but anything less sordid it is hard to imagine [SEP] One can only feel sorry for those generations of Europeans whose own sexual inhibitions prevented them from seeing it that way [SEP] "Mr Keay explores literature (such as the Ramayana), the leftovers of earlier civilisation (such as coins), architecture (Buddhist, Hindu and Moslem), and paintings [SEP] There are a couple of add-on chapters that seem a bit out of place, concerning flora and fauna [SEP] But I was a little disappointed that there was nothing of mathematics, astronomy, music [SEP] But having said that, this is a good read and a great adventure story that features some extraordinary people

but anything less sordid it is hard to imagine [SEP] One can only feel sorry for those generations of Europeans whose own sexual inhibitions prevented them from seeing it that way [SEP] "$T$ explores literature (such as the Ramayana), the leftovers of earlier civilisation (such as coins), architecture (Buddhist, Hindu and Moslem), and paintings [SEP] There are a couple of add-on chapters that seem a bit out of place, concerning flora and fauna [SEP] But I was a little disappointed that there was nothing of mathematics, astronomy, music [SEP] But having said that, this is a good read and a great adventure story that features some extraordinary people

Despite its cover '$T$' has little to do with bedraggled young women who smoke [SEP] It's actually a very cleverly plotted story about a young girl on a island off Ireland who is claimed to be the messiah [SEP] A reporter is sent out to chronicle events and, to no surprise, all is not what they appear to be [SEP] '$T$' is fresh and funny [SEP] It lamblasts both the (Catholic) church and Irish society in equal measure without taking it all too seriously [SEP] Only the most sensitive will be offended ( [SEP] although much of the language is crude) [SEP] I should also add that the book is rather Irish-centric [SEP] Folks from outside Ireland/Britain might not understand much of the verbage or the sarcastic humour [SEP] Bottom line: perhaps Colin Bateman's best book [SEP] No small praise

$T$'s latest novel, "The Last Temptation," is an ambitious undertaking [SEP] The author crosses geographical boundaries; her plot lines involve police forces in England, Holland and Germany [SEP] This novel also has numerous characters and several storylines that at first seem unrelated, but which eventually intersect [SEP] Carol Jordan is an ambitious Detective Chief Inspector who is well trained in criminal intelligence [SEP] Jordan has helped bring two serial killers to justice and she has paid her dues as a police officer [SEP] Now, she is aiming for a high-level job in British intelligence and analysis, and she is expecting a promotion to come through very soon [SEP] Much to her surprise, Jordan is not granted her promotion [SEP] Instead she is sent into deep undercover to bring down a notorious criminal named Tadeusz Radecki and his right hand man Darko Krasic, who are based in Germany [SEP] A second protagonist in "The Last Temptation" is Dr [SEP] Tony Hill, a psychologist who has been deeply scarred by his job of profiling serial killers [SEP] He is now on the trail of a criminal who targets psychologists and murders them in a particularly gruesome manner [SEP] Hill and Jordan have collaborated professionally in the past [SEP] As they work these difficult cases, Jordan and Hill provide one another with much needed advice and emotional support [SEP] McDermid handles her large cast of characters and a complex plot adroitly [SEP] Her dialogue is crisp and her descriptive writing is vivid yet understated [SEP] The author ratchets up the tension as the novel reaches its exciting denouement [SEP] Unfortunately, McDermid resorts to a pat ending, which strains believability [SEP] However, this quibble aside, I recommend "The Last Temptation [SEP] "  McDermid's skill as a writer of fast-paced and well-crafted thrillers makes this new novel a "must-read" for fans of this genre

I just finished "$T$" and wasn't overly  impressed [SEP] Certainly, it was better than "Skylar", but that's  like saying Cheez in a Can is better than those Cracker Barrel fake cheddar  sticks [SEP] Neither one really takes the blue ribbon, but at least you can  squeeze Cheez in a Can directly into your mouth, without having to waste  time cutting it [SEP] In "Skylar", yankee cousin Jonathan  Whitfield is a fish out of water when he comes south for a visit [SEP] In this  installment, MacDonald turns the tables and has good ol' boy Skylar venture  north to visit the very rich Whitfields, where he is, yes, a fish out of  water [SEP] The family jewels are heisted, a young lady is murdered and general  hilarity ensues [SEP] Or doesn't [SEP] As a reader, I never like easy jokes [SEP] I  figure the reason I'm paying to read an author's book is because he or she  is much cleverer than I and will say things that I haven't already thought  or write things that aren't cliches and because of this, I am increasingly  saddened by Gregory MacDonald's descent into mediocrity [SEP] None of the  characters here are much better than stereotypes and the situations they  encounter are downright unlikely [SEP] Add to that the fact that one of the  characters, a Boston blue blood since before the revolution, makes a  personality change likely to cause a whiplash in anyone paying even the  most casual attention and you have a book that is unlikely to win MacDonald  any new fans

$T$ is one of the best books I've ever read [SEP] A well written novel by Lynn Reid Banks weaves good and evil into a touching and unforgetable novel [SEP] The story is this: Mrs [SEP] Cuthbert is expecting a child, but has twins [SEP] One child is so   angelic, it's like a piece of heaven came [SEP] The other one so incredibily devilish,she frequently scares people [SEP] Angela helps, while Diabola hinders [SEP] The story is worked around how the sisters cope with other people, and each other [SEP] When finished, you will be so familiar with these characters, you will wish their was a second book!

Book: $T$Author: Paul ZindelNumber of Pages: 122Publisher and Publication Date: 1969 Harper and Row publishersISBN: 0-553-27324-8Price (if available) and whether it is paperback or hardback: Hardback 	   Imagine if you had parents that never trusted, or that never would believe you [SEP] Or even worse what if you had a stepparent that would call u some pretty bad names and your mom would take his side [SEP] Well that is kind of what this book is about [SEP] 	The main characters in $T$ are two girls named Liz and Maggie [SEP] They are of course best friends [SEP] They are also both seniors in high school [SEP] It is about time for prom and they both have dates [SEP] But you'll never guess what happens next!!!	I think that this book is a really good book [SEP] Personal I loved $T$ [SEP] It has a really good moral [SEP] It was just like a real story [SEP] Everything in this book is based on what is happening in real life [SEP] That is just my opinion [SEP] 	 When I read this book it reminded me of one of my friends sister [SEP] She has just graduated and basically the same thing that has happened to one of the girls in this story [SEP] I am not going to tell you the rest but I guess that you will just have to read and find out for your self [SEP] 	I would definitely recommend this book to People in 6th-9th grade [SEP] The main gender that would want to read this book would be girls because of what the story is based on and because they can relate to it the best [SEP] The people that wouldn't like this would be boys [SEP] Why? Because of what it is about [SEP] 	If you really want to know what happens then I guess that you will just have to read and find out what happen next

Though not a fan of fantasy, I do read it occasionally to keep up on what my students are reading [SEP] The richly imagined descriptions in this series made it one that I enjoyed reading [SEP] An asthmatic seventh grade boy, $T$, is the hero for this seven book fantasy [SEP] Handicapped and with the odds always against him, he does not give up trying to do what's right [SEP] A rich stew of surreal Alice in Wonderland-type imagery and characters, elements reminiscent of myths, an alternate universe, endless hair's breadth escapes, grisly horror, and mystery, Keys to the Kingdom never lags [SEP] However, this series is not just a vividly imagined movie in print for a happy reader to follow [SEP] Keys to the Kingdom is a thinking kid's fantasy [SEP] If one pays close enough attention, answers to the great questions of the origins of our world and our human natures might come close to being answered [SEP] Well-liked by both boys and girls in my middle school classes, this series is favored by boys; and though written at a seventh grade reading level, is also well-liked by high school boys into about tenth grade [SEP] The interest level is rated at grade five through eight [SEP] Both the complexity of the plot and the at times nightmare-like imagery may keep this from being a book for fifth grade and under, unless a child in these years is looking to be challenged and a little frightened [SEP] The series starts with Mister Monday and moves through each day of the week: Grim Tuesday, Drowned Wednesday, Sir Thursday, Lady Friday, Superior Saturday, and the eagerly awaited and yet un-named Sunday episode [SEP] Gaby Chapman

As a fan of $T$'s previous series, the Abhorsen Triology, and The Seventh Tower, as a teen I looked towards his new budding series, shortly after its publication [SEP] There were few reviews for the book, but it seemed promising [SEP] It was indeed, promising, as described before by others [SEP] The book starts out with an inspector of a document thousands of years old [SEP] Sealed within a small fragment, the Will of the Architect, she who had created this realm and all that inhabit it, her Will had been sealed away, over time the ecurity had become lax, for Sloth has taken over the Lower Atrium of the House [SEP] Unfortunently, the Will has unknowingly enlisted help [SEP] A higher power sneaks through the inspector a small line of text, later proving to be more then enough help to free the first several paragraphs of the Will [SEP] Here the story begins [SEP] Arthur Penhaligon is an average adolescent, provided he is asthmatic [SEP] It turns out his new gym teacher is ignorant, horrid, and seemingly loves to flaunt his superiority over kids [SEP] Arthur seems to grimace quite a bit over how he was forced to run the cross-country course, even though he had just recovered from a near death situation, due to his choosing of disregarding the use of his inhaler [SEP] Fatal, later this choice nearly kills him, until he is saved by a fine-dressed man in a [SEP] what seems to be a bath tub-wheeled chair, and a sickly looking butler from the old movies, his uniform long overdue for patchwork and replacement of gloves, and such things, he inherits a blade-like key, and the Compleat Atlas of the House [SEP] Unknowingly to Arthur, the key is what saves him from death, and regretably, seals his fate to embarking on a quest to save another dimension from the ruins of the "Days", although this is what saves his life, he soon begins to regret ever becoming the heir to first key, and so begins the start of the series of The Keys to the Kingdom [SEP] I do reccomend this book to those who: [SEP] a [SEP] ) Like to read [SEP] -enjoy the genre of fantasies, of a unknown world, as $T$ weaves a wonderful tale of the things that will open your eyes to a different world [SEP] b [SEP] ) Those who would like something different, yet similar to all the books that speak of magic, sorcery, and untold secrets of world that we behold only the back of our minds, somethign we wonder could ever exist [SEP] After reading the first three books, I found that the author's note at the end about the different days of the week seems to pertain to the trecherous days [SEP] Mondays were a bit too early in the week as work days (which explains the Sloth condition of Mister Monday) [SEP] Tuesdays were lucky days, so it seems to be in the book also (look on to reviews on Grim Tuesday in the series) [SEP] Wenedsday was a good day (look into other reviews on Drowned Wenedsday) [SEP] I re-read this book recently, and decided that I should try reccomending this book to others $T$ stigmatizes Freudianism as a secular religion, where the Unconscious (a new version of the Original Sin) is treated as a Revelation, with a sharp distinction between the sacred (those under analysis) and the profane, between the good (the true believers) and the bad, and where reason must be suspended [SEP] Freud's concepts are untestable (the experience - transfer - between analysand and analyst is unique) and nebulous (reality can always be made conform to the system) [SEP] His basic technique is free association which should lead to the uncovering of repressed mental contents and correspondent therapeutic consequences for the patient [SEP] The only testable component of the theory are its therapeutic claims, but the effectiveness of the therapy is extremely dubious and unproven [SEP] For the author, Freudianism is a self-perpetuating, falsification-evading, closed system, which controls its own database [SEP] In one word, it is a pseudo-science [SEP] Its enormous vested interests (also financial) are cultivated and protected by a guild: UNATO (United Nations Analysis and Therapy Organization) [SEP] This brilliantly written, corrosive text contains excellent short evaluations of Nietzsche, Marx, Berkeley, Plato and Stoicism [SEP] A must read for all guild-members and outsiders

$T$ and Sean seem to be a smooth and sophisticated senior high school couple [SEP] They introduce their awkward friends Maggie and Dennis to each other [SEP] Underneath the veneer of success $T$ and Sean have problems with their parents and each other [SEP] Do their parents understand or even care about them?  Are they ready for sex?  Meanwhile can Maggie and Dennis learn to communicate enough to stay together? [SEP] This book is Paul Zindel's second and was first published way back in 1969 [SEP] Life has changed since then, such as the free availability of legal abortion, but much of the story is still surprisingly relevant to modern life [SEP] $T$ and Maggie are the main characters so this could be described as a book for girls, but the lives of Sean and Dennis are also described in important sub-plots [SEP] The story is basically a double romance but Zindel has too much of a grip on the ugliness of life to describe the book as 'romantic [SEP] '  This is not Mills and Boon stuff [SEP] To tell the truth I find this novel one of Zindel's less successful works [SEP] To my mind there is nothing in the story to make it really memorable [SEP] But then again Zindel is so far above other writers that I would certainly still recommend reading the novel [SEP] I should also add that I am largely interested in coming of age stories about boys, so maybe I am biased

[SEP] This book is Paul Zindel's second and was first published way back in 1969 [SEP] Life has changed since then, such as the free availability of legal abortion, but much of the story is still surprisingly relevant to modern life [SEP] Liz and Maggie are the main characters so this could be described as a book for girls, but the lives of Sean and Dennis are also described in important sub-plots [SEP] The story is basically a double romance but Zindel has too much of a grip on the ugliness of life to describe the book as 'romantic [SEP] '  This is not Mills and Boon stuff [SEP] To tell the truth I find this novel one of Zindel's less successful works [SEP] To my mind there is nothing in the story to make it really memorable [SEP] But then again Zindel is so far above other writers that I would certainly still recommend reading the novel [SEP] I should also add that I am largely interested in coming of age stories about boys, so maybe I am biased

This started as a promising $T$ [SEP] I couldn't put it down in the beginning [SEP] It was a real $T$ about a real boy in an exciting, intriguing situation [SEP] Then, somewhere in the middle, it just got weirder and odder and more confusing [SEP] And the stranger it got, the less interested I felt [SEP] It was difficult to visualize a world where every single thing (everything!) is unfamiliar [SEP] People don't look like people [SEP] Buildings don't look like buildings [SEP] It was hard to care about the side characters, because they were so bizarre [SEP] I love fantasy and science fiction, but this $T$teller forgot something very important [SEP] The reader needs something familiar to help them relate to the $T$ and characters [SEP] I definitely won't read the rest of this series [SEP] Blah! The sophistication and talent that a writer needs to maintain two plot lines and ferry seven characters through a full-length novel, may be a challenge to author $T$, but she does it with style, believability and panache in THE LAST TEMPTATION [SEP] A serial killer is targeting psychologists in Germany and Holland [SEP] When an old friend is murdered, former British profiler Tony Hill reluctantly gets back into the game [SEP] His job is to outsmart the killer and prevent any more brutal "mutilation" deaths [SEP] At the same time, Carol Jordan, a very ambitious DCI and the love of Hill's life, is offered any position she wants if she does her superiors a "favor" --- seduce Tadeusz Radecki into a sting that will expose his drug, arms and people smuggling businesses [SEP] This seems to be an offer she can't refuse [SEP] But, by the time she finds out that she's been set up, it's too late to back out [SEP] She feels betrayed and used when she discovers that she is the "twin" image of Katerina Basler, Tadisck's lover who was killed in a mysterious hit and run accident [SEP] Hill's murder investigation eventually brings him to Berlin [SEP] And, although he must travel to several European cities, he takes a small apartment in the same building as Jordan [SEP] Both of them work with local cops, Jordan with Petra Becker in Germany, and Hill with Brigadier Marijke van Hasselt from Holland [SEP] THE LAST TEMPTATION is an aggregate of pristine prose, complicated plot twists, roller coaster pacing, intelligent characters, and very interesting subject matter [SEP] McDermid writes with finesse and her extraordinary storytelling prowess sets her new book apart from the ordinary [SEP] Wow! This book is a sure fire winner [SEP] --- Reviewed by Barbara Lipkien Gershenbaum

$T$ was an alright book; the author is pretty talented, except it wasn't too hard or complex to follow, which usually forms the best kind of mystery [SEP] The killer was only mildly surprising, and so was how the killer  would get caught [SEP] But it's still a fine read, so go ahead and check it out [SEP] :)

Termed "America's New National Pastime" by USA Weekend, basketball has come a long way since 1891, when a Massachusetts teacher experimented with an overinflated ball and a peach basket [SEP] This vibrantly illustrated and informative $T$ offers fans up-to-the-minute reporting on the 1995-96 season, superstar and team histories, stats, and more [SEP] 160 color photos

$T$ lives in a world that closely resembles our own - in fact may be our own in the near future [SEP] A deadly flu pandemic killed his parents when he was  a baby and also apparently allowed the federal government to assume sweeping powers, and his adoptive mother is a medical researcher [SEP] An asthmatic, Arthur suffers an attack when in gym class at his new school, and while he is waiting for medical assistance, two strangely garbed men give him what appears to be the minute hand of a clock [SEP] This simple action changes his life for good [SEP] Arthur now becomes the target of increasingly frightening attacks by mysterious men, some with faces that resemble dogs, and a new illness known as the "sleepy plague" appears in his town [SEP] He eventually finds his way into a bizarre realm known as the House, which turns out to be, essentially, the "Command and Control" center for the rest of the universe [SEP] He also learns that after creating the universe from Nothing (which is an actual substance in this "mythology"), the Architect mysteriously departed, leaving a will in the hands of seven trustees, the Morrow Days, who have become corrupt and are now running things to suit themselves [SEP] However, the first part of the Will, which is a living entity, has escaped and engineered the transfer of part of Monday's Key (the minute hand) into the possession of a mortal, Arthur, who is now the Architect's Heir [SEP] Arthur's only hope, if he is to survive and stop the plague in his own world, is to obtain the rest of the Key from Mister Monday and accept his status as Heir, however little he wants it [SEP] Garth Nix's originality, while not of the same type as Philip Pullman's, never ceases to amaze me [SEP] He also possesses a certain sly humor and, like Pullman and J [SEP] K [SEP] Rowling, makes numerous allusions to literary, mythical and cultural traditions far and wide [SEP] In the House, Arthur encounters Suzy Turquoise Blue, a cheeky Cockney girl from the 17th century of his own world and one of the "Piper's Children"; the personified Will itself in the form of a tiny frog with a penchant for jumping down people's throats; the "Old One," whose identity should be obvious to anyone with an interest in classical mythology, and assorted other Denizens [SEP] Arthur is a sympathetic but flawed character and Nix, without preaching or moralizing, manages to portray his compassion and a strong sense of right and wrong that truly make him worthy to be the Architect's Heir [SEP] Suzy, although a secondary character, is brave and resourceful as well as funny, and without her, Arthur probably would not have survived his first hour in the House [SEP] The Will, both in frog and human form, is wonderfully quirky and cranky, and even Mister Monday turns out not to be irredeemable [SEP] As with a lot of the best young adult books out there, some kids may find this series disturbing, and there are some scenes that contain a certain amount of violence

and J [SEP] K [SEP] Rowling, makes numerous allusions to literary, mythical and cultural traditions far and wide [SEP] In the House, Arthur encounters Suzy Turquoise Blue, a cheeky Cockney girl from the 17th century of his own world and one of the "Piper's Children"; the personified Will itself in the form of a tiny frog with a penchant for jumping down people's throats; the "Old One," whose identity should be obvious to anyone with an interest in classical mythology, and assorted other Denizens [SEP] Arthur is a sympathetic but flawed character and Nix, without preaching or moralizing, manages to portray his compassion and a strong sense of right and wrong that truly make him worthy to be the Architect's Heir [SEP] Suzy, although a secondary character, is brave and resourceful as well as funny, and without her, Arthur probably would not have survived his first hour in the House [SEP] The Will, both in frog and human form, is wonderfully quirky and cranky, and even Mister Monday turns out not to be irredeemable [SEP] As with a lot of the best young adult books out there, some kids may find this series disturbing, and there are some scenes that contain a certain amount of violence

target of increasingly frightening attacks by mysterious men, some with faces that resemble dogs, and a new illness known as the "sleepy plague" appears in his town [SEP] He eventually finds his way into a bizarre realm known as the House, which turns out to be, essentially, the "Command and Control" center for the rest of the universe [SEP] He also learns that after creating the universe from Nothing (which is an actual substance in this "mythology"), the Architect mysteriously departed, leaving a will in the hands of seven trustees, the Morrow Days, who have become corrupt and are now running things to suit themselves [SEP] However, the first part of the Will, which is a living entity, has escaped and engineered the transfer of part of Monday's $T$ (the minute hand) into the possession of a mortal, Arthur, who is now the Architect's Heir [SEP] Arthur's only hope, if he is to survive and stop the plague in his own world, is to obtain the rest of the $T$ from Mister Monday and accept his status as Heir, however little he wants it [SEP] Garth Nix's originality, while not of the same type as Philip Pullman's, never ceases to amaze me [SEP] He also possesses a certain sly humor and, like Pullman and J [SEP] K [SEP] Rowling, makes numerous allusions to literary, mythical and cultural traditions far and wide [SEP] In the House, Arthur encounters Suzy Turquoise Blue, a cheeky Cockney girl from the 17th century of his own world and one of the "Piper's Children"; the personified Will itself in the form of a tiny frog with a penchant for jumping down people's throats; the "Old One," whose identity should be obvious to anyone with an interest in classical mythology, and assorted other Denizens [SEP] Arthur is a sympathetic but flawed character and Nix, without preaching or moralizing, manages to portray his compassion and a strong sense of right and wrong that truly make him worthy to be the Architect's Heir [SEP] Suzy, although a secondary character, is brave and resourceful as well as funny, and without her, Arthur probably would not have survived his first hour in the House [SEP] The Will, both in frog and human form, is wonderfully quirky and cranky, and even Mister Monday turns out not to be irredeemable [SEP] As with a lot of the best young adult books out there, some kids may find this series disturbing, and there are some scenes that contain a certain amount of violence

$T$, a retired L [SEP] A [SEP] cop now living in rural Washington state, whose background may be a little murky, is surprised by a visit from a high school semi-buddy who wants his help with a murdered family and a disappeared husband who may have been onto some highly secretive organization [SEP] Jack is reluctant to help until his own wife disappears while supposedly on a business trip to Seattle, and he learns that she may be involved with the same company the missing man was investigating/working with [SEP] When Jack's wife Amy reappears as if nothing is wrong but begins to act just a little bit "not Amy," he finds himself in an uneasy team with the old buddy, Fisher, trying to ferret out the truth behind a shadowy group whose members seem to be hiding some truly strange things [SEP] There is also a concurrent subplot, quite connected to the larger plot, involving a 9 year old girl who also goes missing but finds herself doing and thinking things far beyond her young capabilities, much to her confusion [SEP] The noir style of writing in Jack's portions of the narrative are wonderful and cleverly hard-boiled [SEP] Marshall throws in a bit of the supernatural and even SciFi, but the character of Jack and his determined progress keep this tale grounded firmly on the personal issues [SEP] I was afraid the book would veer into some "it's all aliens!" territory, but its focus stays earthbound, and the dramatic tensions build nicely to its climax, with a smooth denouement that makes sense

This $T$ surprised me [SEP] Given the title and the cover photo, I expected a more hostile discussion of marriage [SEP] What the $T$ offers instead is a well thought out, articulate discussion of marriage in the 21st century [SEP] I've long been perplexed by the number of wedding related shows on cable TV, and I've been truly astonished by what people are paying for their weddings [SEP] I suppose it's a byproduct of our sexually "liberated" age that brides wear white even after having children, being divorced, etc [SEP] so that the beautiful white dress no longer means "brand new bride" [SEP] The author explains the "Wedding Industrial Complex" that drives the image of the "perfect" wedding at the expense of all sensibilities [SEP] At the center of this, of course, is The Dress, that iconic image of marital bliss [SEP] The $T$ also discusses wifely history, and of great concern to me these days, what women and men are doing about The Name Problem [SEP] I never thought it would still be an issue so many years on [SEP] but it is, and it's relevant, and we still don't have good solutions [SEP] In spite of the cover shot, this $T$ is not anti-marriage [SEP] It is, however, anti-stupidity about marriage and weddings in particular [SEP] Read it if you are planning to get married, and read it if like me, you've been there, done that, and are doing it again soon [SEP] (I am truly mystified by why a second time bride would wear white, however [SEP] White speaks of marriage as a brand new thing [SEP] I do believe it should be left to first time brides, preferably those without kids, as white dresses after kids are still just silly [SEP] Yes, I know that's old school of me, and I really wish I felt differently [SEP] it's a matter of etiquette, not morality, however, in my case [SEP] )

My relationship with Australian author $T$ is an odd one [SEP] My first introduction to Nix was in middle school when I attempted to read his famous Sabriel novel after being relentlessly urged to do so by friends [SEP] I couldn't get further than one hundred pages [SEP] It was so excruciatingly boring that I had to stop -and I rarely give up on books that after I've begun them [SEP] Considering my taste in literature, Nix's books should fit perfectly with my preferences, but something about them just falls short [SEP] I thought I'd try again with the first book in Nix's The Keys to the Kingdom series, Mister Monday [SEP] The book is very similar to the Percy Jackson and the Olympians series, and is even being touted as the next Harry Potter [SEP] I can definitely see the connects between Mister Monday and these other series, but there is little else there besides the fact that Mister Monday is a somewhat dark, young adult fantasy novel [SEP] Mister Monday follows the story of Arthur Penhaligon who, during an asthma attack, is entrusted with a magical key by the mysterious Mister Monday [SEP] Not long after, Arthur's hometown is ravaged by an unexplainable plague [SEP] In order to fight the plague, Arthur decides to enter the House (which only he can see) to find a cure [SEP] He ends up meeting an odd collection of characters that have some connection to time, setting the House back on its course, and of course, finding a cure for the plague [SEP] The book is about as confusing and boring as it sounds [SEP] It took me a considerable amount of time to get into it, only to find that the plot makes little to no sense [SEP] This confusion is only helped by the fact that Nix tends to rely on extremely vague descriptions of characters and environments that leave the reader wondering where the characters are and what they look like [SEP] The characters themselves are paper thin [SEP] While Nix creates some unique characters and a fairly interesting hierarchy My relationship with Australian author Garth Nix is an odd one [SEP] My first introduction to Nix was in middle school when I attempted to read his famous Sabriel novel after being relentlessly urged Considering my taste in literature, Nix's books should fit perfectly with my preferences, but something about them just falls short [SEP] I thought I'd try again with the first book in Nix's The Keys to the Kingdom series, Mister Monday [SEP] The book is very similar to the Percy Jackson and the Olympians series, and is even being touted as the next Harry Potter [SEP] I can definitely see the connects between Mister Monday and these other series, but there is little else there besides the fact that Mister Monday is a somewhat dark, young adult fantasy novel [SEP] Mister Monday follows the story of $T$ Penhaligon who, during an asthma attack, is entrusted with a magical key by the mysterious Mister Monday [SEP] Not long after, $T$'s hometown is ravaged by an unexplainable plague [SEP] In order to fight the plague, $T$ decides to enter the House (which only he can see) to find a cure [SEP] He ends up meeting an odd collection of characters that have some connection to time, setting the House back on its course, and of course, finding a cure for the plague [SEP] The book is about as confusing and boring as it sounds [SEP] It took me a considerable amount of time to get into it, only to find that the plot makes little to no sense [SEP] This confusion is only helped by the fact that Nix tends to rely on extremely vague descriptions of characters and environments that leave the reader wondering where the characters are and what they look like [SEP] The characters themselves are paper thin [SEP] While Nix creates some unique characters and a fairly interesting hierarchy Considering my taste in literature, Nix's books should fit perfectly with my preferences, but something about them just falls short [SEP] I thought I'd try again with the first book in Nix's The Keys to the Kingdom series, Mister Monday [SEP] The book is very similar to the Percy Jackson and the Olympians series, and is even being touted as the next Harry Potter [SEP] I can definitely see the connects between Mister Monday and these other series, but there is little else there besides the fact that Mister Monday is a somewhat dark, young adult fantasy novel [SEP] Mister Monday follows the story of Arthur Penhaligon who, during an asthma attack, is entrusted with a magical key by the mysterious Mister Monday [SEP] Not long after, Arthur's hometown is ravaged by an unexplainable plague [SEP] In order to fight the plague, Arthur decides to enter the $T$ (which only he can see) to find a cure [SEP] He ends up meeting an odd collection of characters that have some connection to time, setting the $T$ back on its course, and of course, finding a cure for the plague [SEP] The book is about as confusing and boring as it sounds [SEP] It took me a considerable amount of time to get into it, only to find that the plot makes little to no sense [SEP] This confusion is only helped by the fact that Nix tends to rely on extremely vague descriptions of characters and environments that leave the reader wondering where the characters are and what they look like [SEP] The characters themselves are paper thin [SEP] While Nix creates some unique characters and a fairly interesting hierarchy within the $T$, it falls flat on its face because the characters are underutilized and not given enough time and attention to mature [SEP] I personally disliked the lack of a group of constant supporting characters in the novel [SEP] While there were a few, they appeared so little that they didn't have time to make an impact on the reader [SEP] That's the biggest difference between The Keys to the Kingdom and Percy Jackson and Harry Potter [SEP] The two latter (and more successful) series have wonderful collections of supporting characters, while Kingdom spends so much time trying to explain the plot and the world that their is little time for anything else [SEP] I think that there are some wonderful ideas here, but I Nix simply didn't take the time to adequately develop them for the novel

How did the language of $T$ become the dominant idiom in which the middle classes of the industrialized West speak about their emotions? Ernest Gellner offers a forceful and complex answer to this intriguing question in The Psychoanalytic Movement [SEP] This landmark study argues that although $T$ offers an incisive picture of human nature, it provides untestable operational definitions and makes unsubstantiated claims concerning its therapeutic efficacy [SEP] In a new foreword Jose Brunner expands on the central argument of The Psychoanalytic Movement [SEP] Placing Gellner's work in the context of contemporary hostile critiques of Freud, Brunner argues that these two blatantly different thinkers might also be seen as kindred spirits

In a tearful heartwarming story, we see that $T$ has a next of kin [SEP] With her hands full with two little kittens, $T$ is unable to leave her cat box (with the kittens) to sleep with Nicky [SEP] Two of Nicky's friends come by to visit $T$ and the kittens, wishing that they themselves had a kitten [SEP] The kittens actually want homes of their own [SEP] Nicky decides to give the two kittens to the very same (two young girls) friends who were admiring them [SEP] The two girls' families are shown, happy, with $T$'s kittens [SEP] While Nicky and $T$ are sad at first, they both realize that it's what's best for all involved, and $T$ resumes sleeping with Nicky again

This $T$ was a chore to read [SEP] The cover information presented this work as a balanced description of life as a wife [SEP] Instead, it appears to have been written by a woman with a chip on her shoulder with a pessimistic view of society and women's abilities to think for themselves [SEP] She gives more power and validity to pop-culture than it deserves and puts a negative spin on happy, non-harmful traditions [SEP] It left a sour taste in my mouth [SEP] There are much better guides for women out there that don't have their own agendas

Smashing success [SEP] $T$ entices  Tony Hill to join with  Dutch and German Detectives to try and capture a serial killer that drowns his victims then scalps their pubic hair for his collection [SEP] Not one to avoid the grisly,  McDermid provides plenty in this fast paced thriller-mystery that follows two stories, Jordan's attempt to con a notorious drug and human smuggling crime boss in Germany  and the serial killer who moves between Holland And Germany with ease to dispatch his victims [SEP] Jordan and Hill seem to have overcome their personal problems that kept them apart in previous mysteries but a vicious twist at the end portends a troubled future for them [SEP] Excellent plotting and character development [SEP] A joy to read

$T$ built a story like no other [SEP] Using the old theme of parallel universes and kingdoms he transformed a normal 13 year old boy into a hero that holds the primary key to the universe [SEP] Using the seven deadly sins, the seven days of the week and seven different values, we are taken into a House where everything came from [SEP] Arthur Penhaligon and Suzy Blue are two amazing characters, Arthur: a normal boy, asthmatic, not too confident about himself, intelligent and thoughtful [SEP] Suzy: a young girl, sensitive, impulsive, strong and brave [SEP] Both make the story seem real and really adventurous [SEP] There are other great secondary characters as well, Monday's Noon: the bad guy, loyal servant, strong and fierce [SEP] Monday's Dusk: A dark character, a rebel, helps Arthur through some complicated stuff [SEP] And finally, Mister Monday and The Will [SEP] Overall the story is amazing, $T$ is really an incredibly imaginative author and everything he writes is always a great story [SEP] I'd recommend this book to any fantasy fan or any fan of a really good story [SEP] Also read: Grim Tuesday, Drowned Wednesday, Sir Thursday and Lady Friday

$T$ carefully reminds us of the atrocities committed during the Nazi era in Germany in this, the latest release for the Hill-Jordan series in the U [SEP] S [SEP] As opposed to many writers in the serial-killer/police procedural genre, Val $T$ consistently paints vivid, if disturbing, psychological portraits of the diseased mind responsible for the crimes committed in her novels [SEP] Her psychological material is carefully researched and propels the plot along at a brisk pace [SEP] Her writing continues to soar above most of her peers, and the relationship between the two protagonists keeps the reader coming back for book after book [SEP] Well done!

I have read all of the Poirot stories, and this is by far my favorite [SEP] Not only is it the perfect second $T$ to the Poirot series (since the first Poirot story also took place at Styles), it is also the most intricate and brilliant of the Poirot stories [SEP] I have read Agatha Christie all of my life [SEP] I am usually able to pick up on some of her clues and figure out who the murderer might be [SEP] I confess, with this one, I could not [SEP] I loved re-reading it to discover the clues I had missed [SEP] The concept of the murderer who is brilliant enough to manipulate others into doing the job for him is extremely interesting [SEP] I wonder if Agatha Christie decided to kill off Poirot because she knew she could never write anything better than this [SEP] I believe this is the best of the best [SEP] I'm off to read it yet again
